text: BIRDS ARE FLUSHED FROM HIDING. A soldier carrying an auto weapon rises up out of the grass and looks around. A mort shell explodes nearby. There are no sound effects. He see unperturbed. Several more explosions in the field. The soldier motions with his arm and: FIFTY MORE SOLDIERS RISE UP OUT OF THE GRASS More small  explosions.

head_text.subj: FREEZE FRAME

text: With a click-click of a camera -- still no fx.

head_text.subj: THE SOLDIERS RUN THROUGH THE GRASS FOLLOWING THEIR LEADER

text: they do, the platoon leader waves his arms again. FIVE ELEPHANTS CHARGE OUT OF THE SHRUBBERY Through a fiel of small mortar explosions.

head_text.subj: FREEZE FRAME

text: With the click-click of a camera. THE ELEPHANTS CHARGE OUT ACROSS THE PLAINS Each carries a enormous load of supplies, and each is ridden by a soldie with a rifle. A HELICOPTER GUNSHIP DIVES OUT OF THE SKY firing rockets the soldiers and elephants. A tribal mask is painted on t nose of the chopper.

head_text.subj: THE ELEPHANTS REAR UP IN TERROR

text: The soldiers on the elephants stand up and aim rifles at chopper and begin firing. THE CHOPPER ATTACKS THE ELEPHANTS against an African suns

head_text.subj: FREEZE FRAME

text: A door slams o.s. and the figure of RUSSELL PRICE, 30, ap at the top of some stairs. Sleepy-eyed, he pulls on a mul pocketed fishing vest over a baggy shirt. He carries a be up canvas bag over his shoulder. A BLACK WOMAN, 40, sleeps at the lobby switchboard desk.  Another OLD BLACK MAN sweeps the floor. Price mumbles a ' morning' and goes to two vintage WW II vending machines - one for candy, one for Coca-Cola. He buys two candy bars a coke, and begins eating his "breakfast" as he crosses t lobby.

JIMMY, a cab driver, has been sleeping in a chair against the wall. Several street vendors have their wares laid ou on the sidewalk against the hotel. Some are shaded by  makeshift awnings, some are not. Jimmy rises as Price arr there is familiar ritual in their greeting. They cross the street together toward Jimmy's waiting tax a hand-painted purple old American car with the words on door, "New People's Taxi Company" and Jimmy's name in scr above it. Price hands a candy bar to Jimmy.
'Morning, Jimmy, think you could  squeeze me in?
Where is you would care to go at  once, Mr. Price?
Bang-bang.
Twenty dollar.
Price hands him a wad of bills.
You're a thief, Jimmy.
Jimmy smiles broadly, nodding, then points to the sky.
Booteeful picture, huh, snap-snap?
I don't do skies.
The two men get into the strange cab parked in front of a open marketplace just starting to come alive; the cab dri off.

The taxi arrives, and Price gets out. Price ambles over to stand in the early morning shade aga an old building. A hand-painted image of Che Guevarra --  with an X painted over it -- is on one wall. Price pulls joint from his pocket and lights up, taking a hit. The sounds of war machinery soon interrupt the stillness. Price hurries to the corner.

Price pulls a handful of colored rags from his pocket and picks out a yellow kerchief, tying it to his arm. Price t steps boldly into the street in front of the approaching  convoy. He exchanges shouts with an officer in a jeep, an with a motion is given permission to join.

head_text.subj: PRICE CLIMBS INTO THE LAST OF THREE TROOP TRUCKS

text: Each truck is filled with perhaps 25 African soldiers in  khaki, each holding an automatic rifle. Another jeep foll towing a World War II cannon.

head_text.subj: INSIDE THE TROOP TRUCK

text: (cheerily) Hi, guys.

The soldiers look over disinterestedly. Two dozen cases o Coca-Cola are tied to a stretcher among stacks of guns. As Price settles in for the ride, he begins pulling camer from his bag. Quickly and automatically, rarely looking, switches lenses, loads film, and prepares his cameras. He has done this a thousand times. A SINGLE WHITE SOLDIER -- OATES, rises from among the bla and shakily makes his way toward Price. A mercenary dress in a ragged uniform of his own design, carries two machin guns and a .45. He smiles broadly, recognizing Price. HOD slaps Price's hands as if they were teammates.
G'damn, Price, you tuna sucking piece  of raw meat -- whatchyou goin' to  Zambeze for?
Thought I'd get some great shots of  your head gettin' blown to  smithereens.
Smithereens?! Be a great fuckin'  picture, eh?
Be a prize winner.
(proudly) Ya think so? (beat; changing tone) Trade ya some greenies for a joint. (beat) I gotta have a joint.
I'm on the wagon, man, sorry.
(shrugs) Ahh. Dope-wise, this place sucks. (looks around, leans  in confidentially) Lotta fuckin' coons around here, eh?
They nod. He laughs obscenely and deeply.
I thought you were fighting for the  Government?
I am. This is the Government.
These are the Rebels.
Fuck they are. This is a Government  convoy to Calunda.
This is the Abou-Deian Revolutionary  Front.
Pause.
You're shitting me.
Pause. Finally Oates starts laughing uncontrollably.

These guys be pissed if they knew,  eh? (Price nods in  agreement; Oates  suddenly gets serious) This is the dumbest motherfucker I  ever signed up for. Don't pay shit  either. (Price nods in  agreement) Nicaragua. That's the spot. Cheap  shrimp, lotta rays -- real thin in  the spook department too, dig?
The convoy rumbles past a check-point into a small airfie containing a motley collection of DC-3's and old planes. RUSSIAN ADVISORS and THREE CUBAN ADVISORS watch.
Well hell... I wonder where the  fuckin' Guvmint is?

As he speaks, the cab of the truck is rocked with a morta shell and explodes. Soldiers scramble to safety. Some gra the guns being transported. TWO SOLDIERS GRAB THE STRETCHER OF COKE and start running for safety. Smoke and explosions are everywhere -- they  abandon their cargo and run for cover. OATES SCRAMBLES TO SAFE GROUND quickly and instinctively, looking around wildly to "read" the situation. Price dive next to him. A SOLDIER IS HIT AND GOES DOWN NEARBY, staggering towards Price and Oates.

head_text.subj: A DC-3 GOES UP IN FLAMES IN THE BACKGROUND

text: THE WOUNDED SOLDIER REACHES FOR OATES who darts out quick and drags the injured Rebel to safety. PRICE HAS HIS CAMERAS OUT AT ONCE and is firing away. TWO REBEL SOLDIERS POINT TO THE STRETCHER OF COCA-COLA an start moving toward it through the smoke. They want to re the soft drinks. PRICE LEAPS FROM HIS BUNKER AND RACES TOWARD THEM dangero waving and shouting as he does.
Hold it! Hold it!

They don't speak English but stop at his craziness. PRICE STOPS AND AIMS HIS CAMERA, and as he does he motion for the soldiers to continue. P.O.V. THE FRAMED IMAGE -- SOLDIERS, SMOKE AND COKE IN B. As the soldiers move toward the Coke, Price snaps picture after picture.

head_text.subj: A MORTAR EXPLOSION BLOWS THE COCA-COLA TO A MILLION BITS

text: two soldiers stop short -- several more steps and they wo have been killed. Price's intrusion has accidentally save them. The two soldiers run toward safety, bewildered and  scared.

head_text.subj: ON THE AIRFIELD

text: Gradually the airfield comes back to life. Several teams medics run with stretchers from the hut and begin gatheri bodies. Rebel soldiers appear from every conceivable shel and move across the field. Oates emerges and meets Price on the torn up runway amids the rubble. They look around at the devastation.
Well, I guess we know where the  Guvmint is.
(cynically) You can walk to work from here.
Convenient, ain't it?
Oates starts to walk away, then stops and speaks earnestl as if trying to connect to a real world that doesn't exis
My brother just got married.
I don't know your brother.
Suddenly, the distant roar of a jet. All the soldiers on field scan the horizon; Price looks up. The air raid sire goes off.

head_text.subj: A JET DIVES OUT OF THE SKY TOWARD THE AIRFIELD OATES AND
SOLDIERS DIVE TO COVER

text: JET STREAKS OVERHEAD and, instead of rockets and bombs, i drops something else: THE SKY IS FILLED WITH A MILLION PIECES OF PAPER The jet  pulls out and disappears. All is quiet again as the milli papers flutter in the sky above the airfield. Out of frustration a single soldier fires a couple of sho at the paper. Price grabs a piece of paper out of the air. It is:

head_text.subj: A PICTURE OF A SWIMMING POOL IN FRONT OF A CALIFORNIA HOU

text: HE STARES AT THE IMAGE and turns it over. There is writin on the backside in Spanish and Russian. He looks around. OATES WANDERS OVER with a handful of the leaflets.
What's this?
Great shit, eh?
Price tries to read the writing on the back as Oates look at a leaflet familiarly.

U.S. Gummint offers this house to  any Cuban pilot flying Migs for the  Rebels who chooses to defect to  America with a Russian jet. We know  they ain't gonna run off with no  planes -- but the Rebs don't --  They're scared. They start thinking  about that swimming pool. Damn near  smell that chlorine. Starts workin'  on 'em, and pretty soon they don't  let the Cubies near a Mig. Use their  own spook pilots and destroy their  own air force in a week. Guaran-fuckin- teed.
C.I.A.?
(proudly) Smartest guys in the world. (afterthought) Hey, you gotta scoop here, eh? You'll  be famous.
OATES shakes hands with Price who looks at the picture.
(dispassionately) Maybe.
(looking around) I gotta run... have a good one.
Oates heads off across the runway as papers continue blow down out of the sky; Price looks up and speaks to himself
I love Africa.

location: HOTEL ROOMS AT THE NEW PEOPLE'S HOTEL

text: CLAIRE STRYDER, 40, reads a report over the telephone as times the call with a stopwatch. A photograph of Claire's high-school-aged daughter sits on her dresser. ALEX GRAZIER, 50, struggles with his tie and a drink at a dresser in the adjoining room. Their connected rooms are  littered with hand washed laundry and the paraphernalia o their trade -- typewriters, tape decks, books, notes,  pictures. Their love affairs of three years is ending.
(on the phone) "...and so this strange war that  features two provincial governments,  three rival liberation fronts, and  at least twenty-five tribal  associations, grinds into its seventh  year..."

Alex picks up a Melodica, a novelty wind instrument, and  tries to court her with "Caravan" as she files her story. Though mildly put off, she maintains her cool throughout call. He thinks he's Paul Desmond.

"...The Battle for the Airfield at  Abou Deia is just another chapter in  this endless story. From Ndjamena,  Chad, this is Claire Stryder." (beat) No -- you didn't hear any music --  must be the connection. Okay? So  long.
She hangs up and rises more irritated than angered.
Alex, don't play that God damn thing  when I'm filing. (beat) We're late.
Quickly expressed, her anger passes.
It's my party -- we'll be late. You  called it a "strange war" and an  "endless story." If you filed that  story for me, I'd say you were  editorialishing.
I like to editorialize. You drunk?
Alex loves to be melo-dramatic and is quite conscious of ability to charm. He's also aware that it's worn off with her.
Drunk? Only with the memories of  making love with you on the plains  of Fianga as the first Army of  Liberation marched in and opened  fire.
And freed the Proletariat.
Alex raises a drink.
Right.
I'm going to the party without you.
She leaves -- he quickly puts on his coat and follows her
Christ, I don't want to go to this  stupid party. I'm bad at false  modesty.
You're great at it.
She straightens his half-tied tie in an act of familiar  affection rather than motherliness. Nervousness. She spea calmly -- this is ground they have already covered.
Alex, you're going to make a great  anchorman in New York and undoubtedly  I could be a Pulitzer Prize winning  hostess -- but I'm not going with  you.
You can work out of the East Coast.  We'll get a place on Long Island and  burn our suitcases.
I still like suitcases.
Every Saturday night we'll have a  party... invite all our friends, sit  out on the veranda and interview  each other.
I've done all that.
I haven't. (beat; changes tack) Well, God dammit, I'm getting tired  of memorizing who's the president of  the... Republic of Maldives.
Mamoon Abdul Gayoom.
Yeah, he succeeded Mamoon Abdul  Gayeem.
They both smile slightly as the elevator comes to a stop. The door doesn't open, and the light flickers.
And I'm tired of Third World  elevators.
He bangs the door with his fist. It opens, and they enter dismal hallway. The sounds of a party come from beyond.
Don't leave me.
I already have.
As they approach the door to the party, he speaks with ne toughness.
Fuck Abou Deia and New York. I'm  going to Nicaragua with you.
No.
I've heard it's a neat little war  with a nice hotel.

A cheer goes up for Alex as he and Claire enter. Party ha booze, hand-made signs reading "Bon Voyage," etc. Fifteen journalists of varying nationalities cover this backwater war. Though both upset, they act as if everything is normal. PRICE STANDS ON A CHAIR AT THE CENTER summoning Alex who  moves through the group with ease, instantly at home. Pri holds up a bottle of champagne in toast.
Alex, get up here!
Alex climbs on a chair next to Price who puts his arm aro him.
To the man who gave me my first job,  and fired me from my first job...  and gave me my second job...
And fired you from your second job...
Just a few words, Alex.
Impossible! Can't be done! etc.
However miserable, Alex shines in these situations. He ra his hand -- silence.
You may be asking yourself what  exactly are you doing here in this  "strange war, just another chapter  in an endless story... that grinds  into its seventh year..."

Claire slips to the side bar and pours herself a drink,  watching Alex and shaking her head with some affection. JIMMY, THE CAB DRIVER, ENTERS WITH A CAKE covered with  candles. The crowd parts for the cake shaped like the cou of Chad. The crowd begins singing "Caravan" in a half-dru tribute to a man they like and respect. PRICE MOVES AROUND THE ROOM TAKING PICTURES of the party; is all casual, silly, fun. THROUGH CAMERA P.O.V.'S OF ALEX IN A PARTY HAT, whip pan CABBY WITH THE CAKE, whip pan to DRUNKEN JOURNALISTS. THROUGH CAMERA P.O.V. OF CLAIRE -- FREEZE FRAME, pan foll her as she moves through the room -- FREEZE FRAME, she pi up another drink and leaves through a side door -- FREEZE FRAME. ALEX GIVES IN AND JOINS THE SINGING, enjoying his own tri once he has managed to give in to it.

Claire's face is also covered with tears as she smokes,  wandering idly among clothespinned photos. A part of her  life is ending -- life with Alex -- but it's not ending  neatly. A ROW OF HANGING PHOTOGRAPHS catches her eye. She stops a looks closely -- then laughs in spite of herself at a ser of pictures: PHOTO OF A TALL AFRICAN NATIVE WITH A COCK S

head_text.subj: LONG IT IS TIED IN A KNOT
AFRICAN WOMAN
PHOTO
PRICE BLOWING SMOKE RINGS
DAYS.

text: CLAIRE PULLS THE PHOTO OF ALEX AND HER from the clip and  looks at it.

head_text.subj: THE DOOR OPENS, AND PRICE ENTERS

text: Oh. I didn't know you were here.
Sure you did. You were taking pictures  of me all over the room.
Well... yeah... you looked great.  Why aren't you partying?
In a minute.
He notices the picture she's looking at.
I printed that up for Alex.
It wouldn't be the greatest thing  you could give him right now... (beat) We just split up.
Jesus, I'm sorry. Who left who this  time?
I'm the villain... I thought it could  be a little cleaner this time -- me  in Central America, him in New York.
That's pretty clean.
But he's decided to go to Nicaragua  too.
To cover you or the war?
To cover everything.
Silence. Price moves behind her and gently kisses her on ear. She smiles quickly and nervously.
No.
He kisses her on the neck.
For godsakes, Russell, listen.
The sounds of the party can be heard. He ignores them and moves around her, trying to kiss her on the lips. She put her hand over his mouth. Price reacts strongly, flaring slightly and withdrawing.
I don't want to wait for you again.  We've been circling each other since  the Montreal Olympics.
You're a genius of bad timing. (beat) I'm going back to the party.
She heads to the door; Price stays. She stops before gett there, hesitates, then pulls the PHOTO OF THE ELEPHANT fr the string and returns to Price, handing him the photo.
This is a great shot.
Thanks.
I've heard the light in Nicaragua's  even better.

He doesn't respond. They stand for several moments -- the sounds of the party get louder. She turns and heads to Al celebration, leaving Price alone in the darkroom. PRICE LOOKS AT CLAIRE AS SHE LEAVES, stares aimlessly for several moments, then focuses back on his PHOTO OF THE  ELEPHANTS.

gradually PULL BACK to reveal other magazines, candy, cig Nicaraguan toys, all in a corner shop, and finally: A FIRE TRUCK LEADS A PROCESSION through the streets -- a  group of middle class Nicaraguan women carry a banner tha reads "Our Revolution is in Christ" (in Spanish), followe by three Catholic PRIESTS in bright robes, followed by a  sound truck with P.A. system, followed by hundreds of  townspeople carrying banana leaves and religious signs. A are singing a Catholic hymn in a swaying, hypnotic rhythm Small red and black flags are scattered throughout. A CAB DRIVING THROUGH THE STREETS runs into the parade an stops. Price sits in the front seat -- his luggage is tie precariously to the roof. The trunk of the cab has been  smashed in beyond repair. Price hops out of the cab with camera bag -- he doesn't know what the parade is about bu it looks great. He hands the cabbie some money to stay ne
Wait here.

He runs to join the procession. PRICE HOPS ONTO THE RUNNING BOARD OF THE FIRE TRUCK and a simultaneously his light meter is out. HE is surrounded b images: SMALL GIRLS DRESSED AS ANGELS LINE THE STREET,

head_text.subj: TOWNSPEOPLE HANG FROM DOORWAYS AND WINDOWS, ICE CREAM CAR
AMONG RELIGIOUS ICONS, SOLDIERS WITH GUNS STAND IN SMALL
GROUPS ALONG THE PARADE ROUTE.

text: PRICE IS QUICKLY TAKING PICTURES OF EVERYTHING, changing  cameras, occasionally taking a quick light reading; his  actions are instinctive and automatic. Suddenly: TEN YOUNG TEENAGERS BURST INTO THE PARADE They wear red a black handkerchiefs, baseball caps, and strange masks. Th are chanting:
Rafael, Rafael, Rafael... libre o  muerte... Rafael...

A LARGE PAINTING OF THE FACE OF RAFAEL is carried aloft o stick, draped with red and black scarves. PRICE PHOTOGRAPHS the boys and the painting. NATIONAL GUARD SOLDIERS SHOVE INTO THE PARADE Up and down the street they spring into action, running for position  with their guns. An ice cream vendor is knocked down, a mother clutches he "angel" daughter, another child is whisked inside a door the Soldiers break into the procession. THE "MUCHACHOS" WITH RAFAEL TURN TO RUN but realize that soldiers have cut off their escape. THREE SOLDIERS BREAK into the parade and are separated fr the boys only by a group of Priests. Trapped, the boys pa but as the SOLDIERS push towards them: THE PRIESTS BLOCK THE SOLDIERS and intentionally scuffle  with them, allowing the boys just enough time to dart int house. One of the boys drops the picture of Rafael as he  heads in the door. THE CROWD PUSHES FORWARD, the route to the door is blocke off, and the boys escape. SOLDIERS FIND THE PORTRAIT OF RAFAEL and shoot it full of holes with their automatic weapons. PRICE PHOTOGRAPHS "RAFAEL" as his image is ripped to shre with bullets. The singing and the parade march on.

Overlooking Managua is a sub-tropical paradise that seems far removed from a brutal civil war, this one time touris watering hole serves as home base to the international pr The cab pulls up, and Price gets out. The driver unties h luggage from the roof as TWO PRESS CORPS MEMBERS recogniz Price and greet him as an old friend.

location: THE HOTEL POOL AND OUTDOOR BAR

text: ALEX SITS WITH A BEAUTIFUL NICARAGUAN WOMAN, 35, at a tab as PRESS CORPS MEMBERS mingle. A man we will come to know HUB KITTLE, 40, dressed New York casual, table hops in th b.g. PRICE SEES ALEX and sneaks over to drop the Time magazine over his shoulder onto the table in front of him. Without looking up, Alex knows Price has arrived. He smiles.
Welcome to Managua.
They shake hands warmly, and Price sits down. Price point to the cover as a beer is served.
You have something to do with this?

Well... I thought of calling your  photographs "Pictures from a Lost  War"... I'm great at captions -- the  New York editors loved it since none  of them knew where the hell Chad was  anyway -- it legitimized their  ignorance, got you a cover, me a  feature, and packaged a class struggle  in two words. Nifty, eh?
Nifty.
Russell acknowledges ISELA CRUZ sitting with Alex.
I'm Russell Price.
I'm sorry... this is Isela Cruz. She  works for the hotel and helps out as  a translator.
My pleasure.

IN THE BACKGROUND CLAIRE WALKS INTO THE POOL-BAR AREA She carries her handbag and some papers -- she stops short se Price sitting with Alex. She hesitates, starts toward the stops, and sits down at the bar at the opposite end of th pool. Price sees her, and she sees Price. They pretend they don Price turns to Isela and launches into a stream of broken chauvinistic Spanish with his usual elegance.
(in Spanish) Looks like you guys have a lot of  bang-bang down here, eh? Little  misunderstanding between the poets  and the government?
"Misunderstanding?!" "Down here"  it's called a war. It started in  nineteen thirty. Before you were  born.
My Spanish is a little out of shape --  what'd he say?
He said he considers it an honor to  be able to photograph our war.
Price looks at each of them and decides not to push.
Russell's got a way with words.
I can tell.
You're a helluva translator.
I know. I'm much in demand around  here. Will you excuse me? If you  have any questions, just ask.
Alex stands to help Isela from her chair. Price presses o instinctively and effortlessly.
Who is Rafael?
It depends who you ask.
Alex turns to Isela, who stops as she rises.
Rafael? Comandante Rafael. He is  either a Marxist dupe of Russia and  Cuba... (beat) ...or the most popular leader of a  most popular democratic revolution. (to Price cynically) Take your pick.
I don't really give a damn... but  the guy's got a great face.
A beat, then Price asks his question almost sexually, as he thinks he could seduce Isela, Rafael, the whole war.
How would he like to be photographed?
You'd never find him.
Wanta lay odds?
You would lose. (beat) You must excuse me.
She starts to leave again, and again he stops her.
Just one more thing -- is Rafael  owned by the C.I.A. or the K.G.B.?  I'll figure out the rest.
Isela seems to welcome the question. Her tone is less fli and she focuses hard on Price.

Mr. Price... the world is not divided  into East and West anymore. It is  divided into North and South. By the  time you people figure that out --  it will be too late. (beat) Congratulations on your cover.

She touches his Time magazine, kisses Alex on the cheek, floats magically through the pool area. Price frames her with his fingers as if composing a shot. P.O.V. OF ISELA THROUGH PRICE'S FINGERS Isela kisses anot journalist, grabs someone's hand, and lands gracefully at another table.
So far this war's got it all over  Africa.
You're gonna have a ball.
ALEX PLACES HIS HAND OVER PRICE'S "FRAME" blocking out hi view of the sexy Isela. Though Alex's tone is gentle, the threat is obvious.
Hands off. I need an interpreter  more than you do right now.
Price takes the hint.
You still hanging in there with  Claire?
Alex chooses his words carefully and speaks slowly.
I'm hanging in there like an interim  post-war government waiting for the  palace to be overrun... by younger  men.
Silence and an uneasiness that Alex intended. Price manag a smile.
Younger men.

Alex smiles disarmingly. CLAIRE RISES AT THE OPPOSITE BAR, picks up her papers, an heads straight for the two men with a bounce in her step. BOTH MEN ARE A BIT SURPRISED AT HER ENTRANCE and she hand stack of mail to Alex.
Hi, Alex... Russell! When did you  get in?
Just now.
She shakes Price's hand in a friendly manner that comes o awkwardly, then races past the moment to address and ente both men.
You're not going to believe this --  I just beat you guys and everybody  else here to a story... (she teases them) ...exclusive... eat your heart out.
What'd ya get?
I've just been promised a private  interview with Tacho.
(impressed) Congratulations. The bastard won't  talk to me.
Who's Tacho?
They turn to Price as if everyone knows who Tacho is.
That's President Somoza's nickname.
I don't know who the players are  yet.
Want me to order you a hot dog and a  program?
A bit of tension and awkwardness -- Claire quickly takes  control and changes the tone.
Fellas! No fighting after six at  night, all right? Curfew. (beat) C'mon, we've all got something to  celebrate.

Corrugated metal roofs, thatched hut booths, a strange  combination of decorative and architectural devices. DAIS WILLIAMS, a large black woman from Nicaragua, sings "I Le My Heart in San Francisco" with a mediocre jazz group. HUB KITTLE is present, and other journalists drop by the  table to say hello. A BOY PHOTOGRAPHER, 13, aims an ancient bellows type pola at a booth in which Claire sits between Alex and Price. T are holding a pose indefinitely while the boy struggles w the camera. They hold up the TIME COVER and a couple of b in celebration, and when he finally snaps the picture -- flash. The boy puts the camera down disappointedly.
(in broken English) Sometimes it doesn't work.
The three journalists relax their pose.
Let me look.
ON THE BANDSTAND Daisy has just finished "San Francisco" spots Alex, motioning to him.
Ladeez and Gen'mun, hep me get Aaleex  ov' here...
Daisy applauds lightly for Alex to join them. Alex is equ pleased and embarrassed.
There's not many piano bars left  where I'm still welcome.
Go ahead.
If she can't sing in the key of C  I'm in trouble.

Alex excuses himself and joins Daisy on the bandstand. Pr and Claire are left alone in the booth as Price hands the repaired camera back to the boy. ALEX AT THE PIANO begins a slow, easy cocktail version of "Stardust," the song of his generation perhaps, and he se happy, seduced by his own chords. PRICE AND CLAIRE RESUME THEIR POSE, and this time the cam FLASHES. Price pays for the picture from the boy. At first there is a moment of awkwardness between them.
Well...
"Well"... you finished your assignment  in Chad?
Got Africa all wrapped up and pouched  to my editor.
She smiles and relaxes a bit at the typical Price remark.
You're going to love this war,  Russell... there's good guys, bad  guys, cheap shrimp... (an afterthought) And Alex is still singing in the  background. (beat) I missed you.
We gotta get alone somewhere to talk.
ALEX BEGINS SINGING as he plays. He sings like a trumpet  player -- no voice but great phrasing. He half smiles as sings, enjoying the song and enjoying making them  uncomfortable.

head_text.subj: ALEX AT THE PIANO

text: Sometimes I wonder why I spend these  lonely nights, Dreaming of a song...

head_text.subj: BACK AT THE BOOTH

text: Jesus... he's doing it on purpose.
Alex is one of the world's leading  experts on military strategy.
They don't really want to talk about Alex though his pres is unavoidable. Price changes gears, gets slightly goofy, and steers the conversation to more comfortable turf.
Well, hell, I just got off the boat...  gimme the scoop on Nicaragua...

Well... about sixty years ago the  U.S. Marines invaded to protect  American business interests and put  down a peasant revolt led by a little  man who wore a giant cowboy hat -- his name was Augusto Sandino... In  nineteen thirty-four he was murdered  at a peace conference, and the Somoza  family has ruled ever since...
No, no, no... I don't mean the stuff  about the peasants -- I mean the  real stuff.
She knows what he means, but she wants to tease him a bit first.
The "real" stuff?... you mean a  history of class struggle in agrarian  societies?
No, c'mon!

Oh. Okay... well... (beat) Just a couple things. (beat) One -- there's only two kinds of  beer available -- Tona and Victoria.  Victoria's better. (beat) And two -- if you see Miss Panama  hanging around the hotel bar -- hot,  hot, hot -- but don't touch. She  belongs to Tacho, and if anybody  gets caught with her then El  Presidente has promised to personally  cut off the guy's... (unsure which word to  use)
Pecker?
Yeah... and throw it into Lake  Managua.
Jesus.
And the lake's already polluted.

Price is impressed, and yet another new face drops by the booth -- they both recognize and see him coming, a  contemporary of Price, REGIS FLYNN, a scraggly British  journalist who heads over to their table holding three be
(mutters to Claire) Is there anybody here we don't know?
No.
Regis slides into their booth, happy to see them.
G'damn, Price... kudos on the African  snaps. (shakes hands, a  perfunctory kiss on  her cheek) Jeez, Claire, I haven't seen you  since...
Three Mile Island.
Yeah... shit... (wistfully) Holiday Inn, right?
He nods; they all sip beers and watch Alex sing.

A teenage DISHWASHER looks around nervously, then pulls a paper sack from off the shelf, removing a strange mask fr it. He pulls the mask over his head. Then from the bag he removes a hand-made zip gun, puts a bullet in it, and dar into the shadows of a nook, waiting. BACK TO THE BOOTH where Regis softly croons a few bars of "Stardust" into Claire's mike. The three of them are havi a good time, mildly drunk at best, and uninhibited.
As we hear Alex's gentle rendition of the standard, a NEC COUPLE moves back into the shadows of the club. Each pull on a mask, as in the b.g.:

head_text.subj: ISELA AND AN ELEGANT MAN ARRIVE AT THE CLUB

text: The man, somehow out of place, dresses with casual contin style, not overdone but expensive and tasteful -- clearly from another world. He wears a neat hat and moves gracefu Isela looks stunning, dressed for the evening. The DOORMA greets them familiarly. Isela casually checks her watch as they enter the club. The masked couple in the shadows check their watches.

As Isela and the man enter, commanding attention without  trying. Isela stops at the piano long enough to kiss Alex gently before sitting in the booth with the man. IN PRICE'S BOOTH the new arrivals have caught their atten Price and Alex still clown slightly, and Claire teases th
Jesus... Louis Jordan walks in, and  I'm sitting with the Everly Brothers.
Before you fall in love -- that's  Marcel Jazy... friend of wine, women,  and Somoza. They say he's a  businessman...
(interrupting) He's a businessman in search of a  business... he doesn't try very hard  to cover up his connections to the  C.I.A...

head_text.subj: JAZY LIGHTING ISELA'S CIGARETTE

text: But look at his moves -- can the  C.I.A. light cigarettes like that?
What's wrong with the Everly Brothers?
THE WAITER ARRIVES AT PRICE'S BOOTH and sets down three s cocktails and more champagne, as:

location: THE BACK DOOR OF THE CLUB

text: It opens quickly, and three more MEN IN MASKS enter quick BACK TO THE BOOTH as the waiter speaks with a firm coolne
Please stay at your table, and you  won't be hurt.

head_text.subj: A FACE IN A MASK MOVES QUICKLY PAST PRICE'S TABLE

text: ANOTHER MASKED FACE COMES OUT OF THE KITCHEN The dishwash waves a gun.

head_text.subj: TWO MASKED FACES

text: DOOR The woman carries an automatic rifle and guards the  entrance. THREE MASKED FACES APPEAR Almost materialize from thin ai moving silently and without commotion. The music winds do slowly. (Six Guerrillas total) A GUERRILLA QUICKLY SPRAYS AN IMAGE ON THE WALL With a fe deftly drawn strokes, the FACE OF RAFAEL magically appear The name "RAFAEL" is written under the face, then other n and revolutionary slogans. As this takes place:

head_text.subj: A WOMAN GUERRILLA HAS A GUN AT THE HEAD OF A NICARAGUAN

text: BUSINESSMAN The middle-aged, well-dressed local sits with his wife and two other men. They freeze in fear, the nigh freezes, as the GUERRILLAS take control of the room swift and smoothly. ONE GUERRILLA FACES THE NICARAGUAN BUSINESSMAN at the tab and speaks loudly but without panic. The masked Guerrilla around the room are serious but nervous.
(in Spanish) We do not want to waste any ammunition  on a head as empty as yours -- but  we will.
(in Spanish) What is this?!
(in Spanish) Shut up! Get up!

The BUSINESSMAN refuses. The GUERRILLA LEADER takes a han grenade from his pocket and pulls the pin without hesitat then holds the grenade in front of him fearlessly, inches away from the Businessman's face. The Businessman rises slowly. The LEADER motions toward t back door of the club.
(in Spanish) You are coming with us -- you will  not be hurt -- we will trade you for  the release of some Nicaraguans who  care about Nicaragua.

The woman with the gun shoves it into the man's head forc him to move toward the kitchen door. PRICE TAKES PICTURES QUICKLY WITH A TINY CAMERA that fits into the palm of his hand. Neatly, surreptitiously, and c Price is coolest in any crisis. CLAIRE PUNCHES ON HER TINY TAPE RECORDER instinctively, a a tiny red light comes on. THE BUSINESSMAN IS SHOVED TO THE DOOR He hesitates, afrai to leave the room. The Guerrilla shoves the grenade in hi face; the woman sticks the gun into his neck even deeper.

head_text.subj: MASKED GUERRILLA AT THE FRONT DOOR SHOUTS FOR THEM TO HUR
THE BANDMEMBERS

text: BANDSTAND Alex trips over the drum set slightly -- a clan clash of cymbals startles everyone, and as the drama free

head_text.subj: THE KITCHEN DOOR SWINGS OPEN, AND THE BOY PHOTOGRAPHER EM

text: Innocently, the young boy struts out of the kitchen to se what's going on, and as he does the DOOR STRIKES THE ARM THE GUERRILLA WITH THE GRENADE, and: THE GRENADE IS KNOCKED FREE For an instant, everything  freezes, and: THE GRENADE ROLLS ACROSS THE FLOOR Daisy Williams, the si runs away screaming as the grenade comes to rest near a  crowded section of the club. A Guerrilla guarding the side door rushes for it, picks i up, and as he does: THE GRENADE EXPLODES IN THE GUERRILLA'S HAND A brutal  explosion -- the ceiling caves in partially, the musical  instruments explode, and: THE SANDINISTA GUERRILLAS DART FROM THE ROOM through vari doors. The boy photographer lies bloodied. The Guerrilla picked up the grenade is a barely recognizable corpse. Th Businessman is soiled but unhurt. ONE HALF OF THE CLUB BREAKS OUT IN FLAME As a broken gas  pipe feeds a sudden outburst of fire, the club's patrons  panic -- screaming and shoving towards the door as the RO LIGHTS UP, and: PRICE'S LIGHT METER IS OUT AT ONCE followed quickly by a  35mm camera, quickly clicking off picture after picture o the club amid the flames and panic. The new light makes h job easier. PRICE TAKES A LIGHT READING near the body of the boy  photographer. He sees the boy's camera lying nearby. Pric puts away his light meter and feels the boy's pulse, then puts his ear to the boy's heart -- making sure he is not  still alive.

head_text.subj: LA GUARDIA SOLDIERS AND FIREMEN FILL THE ROOM

location: THE PRESS ROOM AT THE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL

text: The chaos of a busy, cramped Telex room. A switchboard -- several journalists trying to place phone calls. Press co and go -- coffee, cigarettes, and half-eaten sandwiches. CLAIRE TEARS A STORY OFF THE TELEX while Price stands to side of the action eating a sandwich and watching. ALEX STANDS AT THE CENTER OF IT ALL Established as the se figure (or one of them) to whom other, younger journalist come for information. A YOUNG JOURNALIST, a Time stringer, is slightly distraug on the phone, and interrupts Alex's dealing with others,  cupping the phone, to announce:
...it's Charlie, from New York --  says that a terrorist bombing of a  Central American restaurant isn't  big enough to hold for the world  section...
Tell him we have pictures.
He knows.
Tell him there were pieces of body  in the piano, and somebody was  singing, "I Left My Heart in San  Francisco." (beat) What's he got better than that?
He's got the Pope visiting Egypt.
Alex grabs the phone in disgust and launches in.

Forget the Pope, Charlie. Every week  you got the Pope somewhere. This is  a very big story down here because  it's the first sign of fighting in  Managua. (beat) Yeah, well get a map and look up  Nicaragua -- ya drive to New Orleans  and turn left.
While Charlie argues on the other end of the phone, Alex  initials papers and performs several jobs at once.

Like hell I'm editorializing, the  whole thing happened in a roomful of  C.I.A. and press. What do you want?! (beats) How do I know they were C.I.A.? They  wore name tags, what do you think?  We're backing a Fascist again -- I  know that ain't news, but see if you  can find an angle!
HUB KITTLE has been floating through the room and, upon  hearing the word "fascist," takes offense and approaches  Alex.
Hey! There's fascists and then there's  fascists, right? Be careful how you  throw words like that around.
Alex ignores Hub though he is slightly pestered by him, a continues on the phone as he initials papers brought to h
We don't have any pictures of Rafael  because nobody knows where the son  of a bitch is, and anybody crazy  enough to go after him...

Alex spots Price who is standing nearby, still eating a  sandwich, still enjoying the high energy buzz of the room Alex directs his next line so that Price cannot fail to g the message. Alex plays the moment coolly.
...is liable to get his nuts shot  off.
Hub nods seriously, in agreement. Price turns. Alex smile Price smiles. Alex hangs up, grumbling, then turns his  attention to the persistent Hub Kittle.
Yeah, well g'bye... (to Hub) Who the fuck are you?
(extending a hand) Hub Kittle. I'm with Lewitsky and  Knupp -- New York. We have a client  down here.
Alex is irritated but fascinated.
Who?
President Somoza.
Alex is incredulous that Somoza employs a New York P.R. f Hub is professionally used to this reaction -- no panic.
I know, I know... (beat) But there's an untold story here. I  mean, the man has a point of view  too, right?
Alex turns to leave; Hub corners him.
We got a national anthem contest  going on right now, and you guys are  ignoring it. Lotta human interest.
Alex turns to other business though Hub persists. ELSEWHERE IN THE ROOM a young NICARAGUAN WOMAN, 18, is ta to Claire. She seems to be part of the local press.
I want you to get me copies of the  Government inventory lists of all  captured Guerrilla weapons. I want  to know if the guns are Israeli,  Belgian, Russian, Cuban...
The Guerrillas are not supplied by  anybody from the outside.
Fine -- give me proof.
A TELEPHONE OPERATOR CALLS TO CLAIRE through the chaos.
Su hija, su hija! Your daughter from  Los Angeles.

Claire sighs at the bad timing but seems delighted to be  interrupted by her daughter, and brushes aside a Stringer forcing paperwork upon her. Claire takes the phone into a bare, adjacent hallway for some privacy. IN A BARE HALLWAY Claire talks to her daughter.

Hi, baby! How are you? (beat) Has Grandmother spoiled you silly by  now? She has? Good. (beats) Yes, I got your letter with the  picture of your new boyfriend. He's  very good looking... but he's a bit  old, isn't he? No? Just how old is  he?...
P.O.V. FROM THE TELEX ROOM TO CLAIRE Price knows this is his world, and he wanders outside.
Price bounces along, whistling, "San Francisco." An occas Guardia jeep or taxi rumbles past. He strolls up the walk of a house from which comes a strange, blue glow.

Blue walls, bare bulbs, several pictures on the wall, and old woman lying in a hammock. Music in the b.g. Price  approaches her and hands her a $100 bill -- there is a br negotiation of the black market value.
(in broken Spanish) Cuanto?
Quince.
Veinte.
Diezysiete.
She shrugs, declaring the negotiation ended, and leaves t room to change the dollar into cordobas. Price idly studi the pictures on the wall:

head_text.subj: PICTURE OF ANASTAZIO SOMOZA IN WHITE, PICTURE OF THE VIRG
OF GUADALUPE, PICTURE OF SANTA CLAUS, FADED NEWSPHOTO OF
HANK AARON HITTING HIS 715TH HOME RUN.

text: PRICE SMILES AND TURNS RIGHT INTO A SHARP BAYONET mounted a rifle held threateningly by a Guardia soldier. THE SMALL ROOM IS FILLED WITH NATIONAL GUARDS We haven't  heard them enter over the sounds of music and our  preoccupation with the pictures.
What is this? I'm a journalist!
No answer. Price pulls a thick passport and press credent from a pocket, handing them to the Officer in charge.
Journalista, journalista!

The officer looks at Price's passport photo, studies it  briefly and takes the passport. He nods. A rifle butt is jammed violently into Price's belly -- he doubles over. The Officer nods, and Price is led away. As the Guard hauls him outside, the OLD WOMAN appears in doorway with a stack of local currency.
Price is led into a dark cell where another PRISONER, 50, lies in street clothes on the floor. The Prisoner is spat upon by the Guards and kicked awake. Price cringes.
Padre Puta, Padre Puta, Padre Puta... (in Spanish to Price) Here is a Priest for you to confess  your sins.
The Guards laugh and leave. The Prisoner rises to his fee Price keeps his distance. The Prisoner looks in bad shape
Cigarillo?
Price hands him a cigarette and lights it. A long, deep d
Priest? (the man nods) (in broken Spanish) What are you doing here?
(in Spanish) The government accused me of using  the church to hide Rebels and guns.
(in Spanish) Governments are always wrong, eh?
(in Spanish) This time they're right. Who are  you?
(in Spanish) Un periodista.
(in Spanish) Whose side are you on?
(in Spanish) I don't take sides. I take pictures.
(in Spanish) No sides?
(in Spanish) No.
The Prisoner Priest looks at Price with disdain.
Periodista Puta, todos periodistas  son putas. (All journalists are  whores)
The Prisoner sits down in the corner ignoring Price who i surprised to be treated so despicably.
(quietly) Go home.

Price is led into a lineup of 10 people, all Nicaraguans. The room is narrow and so brightly lit that at first he c his eyes. FIGURES MOVE IN THE SHADOWS A Guardia soldier moves up an down the lineup, stopping to point at a prisoner. In the  line we recognize the WAITER from the Viking Club. Price  speaks to the soldier in a calm, reasoned tone.
Mi amigo -- mala interpretacion, eh?  Periodista, comprende? Famoso. Time  magazine.
The soldier whirls at Price in a rage out of all proporti to Price's tone, shouting:
(in Spanish) Shut up!

Price holds up his hands -- he may be fearless, but he's stupid. The soldier pulls a knife, then pulls his own ton from his mouth, and makes motions with the knife as if cu out his tongue. The message is clear -- Price doesn't spe The soldier walks up to the Waiter and points. The Waiter frightened. Through the shadows we see an officer talking with a civi in a hat. The civilian points to a door. THE WAITER IS LED AWAY THROUGH A DOOR protesting desperat as he goes. The soldier moves to the next prisoner -- he is led away. This repeats itself until the soldier arrive at price.

head_text.subj: THE SOLDIER POINTS TO PRICE

text: PRICE'S P.O.V. THROUGH THE SHADOWS The civilian is in a  discussion with the officer -- it is clear that his opini affects the decisions. For a moment Price doesn't know wh he's going to be led. The civilian points to a different  door -- it opens -- and Price steps down off the display  rack into a room. THROUGH THE DOOR as Price steps through, the action conti with the other Nicaraguan prisoners. Price looks around  quickly, but the Civilian and Officer are gone. He is qui shown into a bare office.
Pictures on the wall of Somoza and the FLAG RAISING AT IW JIMA. Price's cameras and bag sit on a desk.
rumpled elegance is at odds with the brutal surroundings. The door closes. A SENIOR OFFICER ENTERS THE BARE ROOM, and Price addresse him at once.
Soy un periodista.

(in excellent English) Mr. Price... you must accept our  deepest apologies for the  misunderstanding. Somebody saw you  taking photographs of terrorists  hooligans in the parade and at the  nightclub -- our young officers get  carried away... they're always looking  for traitors.
That film is half way to New York by  now.
I know, I know... It was all a  misunderstanding... una mala  interpretacion. Your cameras.
The Officer reaches for one of Price's cameras and hands to him, but as he does: THE CAMERA DROPS TO THE GROUND AND BREAKS -- SILENCE The  Officer would love for Price to get angry.
I'm sorry.
Price smiles barely, and refuses to pop off.
Forget it.
Price puts his cameras in his bag, and as he is shown fro the room he notices a copy of the TIME MAGAZINE WITH ELEP sitting on the desk.
This way.
Price is shown to a door, handed over to a soldier, and l outside into the night.
Claire stands at the main doorway surrounded by GUARDS, a OFFICER, and an unidentified CIVILIAN -- she is arguing w them in rapid Spanish, not allowing them to get in a word

(in Spanish) You throw a journalist in jail -- it  gets in the papers. You walk all  over the same press credentials you  pass out. I demand to speak to someone  in authority or I'll go to Tacho  myself... I don't understand you --  you're big and strong and handsome  but you're not so smart! (beat) You should be trying to seduce us!
Senora...
PRICE IS SHOWN OUT A DOOR IN THE BACKGROUND and sees her.
Claire!
They hurry toward each other and embrace briefly. The Gua watch it all curiously.
You're okay?
I'm fine -- what're you doing here?  These guys are goons.
They love being beaten up by a woman (beat) I've been looking for you all night --  why'd they lock you up?
They walk away together.
I don't know. Taking pictures. The  usual. Jazy got me released.
Jazy?! You think there's a story  there?
Ahh... C.I.A. stories are all alike.  I wanta find Rafael.
You need help?
No. You?
No. (beat) When should we start.
I figure you probably want to do a  little research on the history of  Marcel Jazy's business connections  in the third world countries with  C.I.A. influence...
Oh. I assumed you'd just look him in  the eye and say "Gimme a break, for  crissakes, Marcel, are you a spy or  aren't you?"

Marcel Jazy stands, drink in hand, looking slightly rumpl in the daylight, slightly older, but more charming and se effacing than his first impression indicated. His two sto Mediterranean style house is in slight disrepair; the gar are scraggly and overgrown. The pool is empty. Jazy addre Price and Claire.
...are you a spy or aren't you, eh?
(smiling) Spy is such an odd word, Mr. Price...  nobody is a... 'spy'... anymore.
Russell prefers pictures to words...
You don't have to apologize... you're  journalists.
And you're a businessman?
A businessman? That sounds good.  Okay, I'm a businessman.
Why was I arrested, and why did you  get me released, and who are you?

As he speaks, the questioning comes to a sudden halt as a SPECTACULAR LOOKING WOMAN emerges from the shadows of the house into the light of the courtyard. She is tall, Latin and besides high heels wears only a shiny, high fashion  swimsuit, cut high on the legs. Price, Claire, and Jazy stop to watch as the woman stops look into the empty pool.
No agua.
(nodding) No agua.
(in Spanish) Oh, Marcel! You told me there would  be water in the pool this week!
Jazy leans in very coolly to Price and Claire as he pours extra glass of wine and speaks softly in English again.
If she dove in, I assure you she  wouldn't notice.
He carries the glass of wine to the woman, smiling warmly
(to Miss Panama in  Spanish) Sweetheart, the Guerrillas knocked  out the pumping station on the road  to Masaya, and we must ration water  for the time being. Next week maybe  things will be better.
(in Spanish) Maybe I should go back to Panama.
(in Spanish) Maybe you should.

Jazy pushes a lounge chair over to her and hands her a gl of wine. The woman unfolds gracefully into a lounge chair the sun. Very sexy. She reaches for and kisses Jazy's han affectionately -- he kisses her forehead. She feels bette now. Jazy motions for Claire and Price to follow him inside.

The pool is visible in b.g. His house, like the pool, is  rumpled and slightly sloppy though it betrays the taste o its occupant -- books everywhere, pictures on the wall,  nothing cheap or tacky but everything is well worn.
You were arrested because the Guardia  are clowns who specialize in excess.  You were released because I told  them to release you.
These are not the normal duties of a  businessman.
He looks at them directly.
But they are the normal duties of  a... spy, eh? You win, I'm a spy. (smiles) There, are you happy? I feel better.
He refills their glasses.
Now we can relax. You can turn off  your little thing.
The red light of her recorder is on. She smiles slightly, undisturbed, and turns it off.

Oh, I trust you won't say anything  to hurt me. In some ways I'm a  terrible spy. I used to be much better  at it, but now it seems everyone  knows who I am. I have too many  girlfriends. I like to be  photographed. (beat) I talk too much.
Price and Claire are almost afraid to speak, afraid to  interrupt this strange performance.
I always talk too much... but my  girlfriends like that... No matter. (pointing to the  swimsuited woman) You know who she is?
No.
That's Miss Panama. Do you know who  that is?
Oh, yeah, yes, etc.

She's in love with me. I've got to  get some water in the pool. (beat) And once a week I have lunch with  President Somoza to discuss security  measures against the Sandinista  insurgents, but all he wants to talk  about is Miss Panama... he's worried  about her.
Claire interrupts with a smile.
Because he thinks she's seeing another  man?
Jazy smiles slightly before confirming.
...and he assigned me to find out  who the man is.
They all smile at this complication. Price is impressed.  Jazy changes the subject with fluent and disturbing ease.
We all know the Revolutionaries are  going to win, don't we?
Silence. They don't know how to respond.
They all are slightly entertained and glad for the relief Unsure what to say next, Price notices a picture on the w

head_text.subj: A BLOWN-UP FRAMED PHOTO OF THE RANCH HOUSE WITH
POOL

text: The same picture we saw on the leaflets in Africa.
There's a rumor about this picture.  Some people say you're a genius --  that you invented this scheme.
It was lots of people's idea... Have  you been to Leon?
We're going to Masaya... they say  the Rebels have hit the cuartel.
It's supposed to be nasty there... a  lotta people think Rafael's in the  South. I want to find out.
No, no, it's not "nasty" yet. Another  week maybe. (beat) You would love Leon. A nice cathedral  and beautiful light... et un peu de  bang-bang.
We're not doing a travelogue, you  understand.
Of course, of course... only I have  heard that Comandante Rafael has  recently had his unit in the area.
(surprised) Rafael is near Leon?
Well... it's a rumor, what do I know?
The voice of Miss Panama.
Estoy desemperado!
She's lonely!
Don't let us stand in the way.
It's my job. (beat) You think I talk too much?

He doesn't wait for an answer, but excuses himself and go out to tend to Miss Panama. P.O.V. OF JAZY AND MISS PANAMA BY THE EMPTY POOL as Jazy  touches her, whispers, and she waves to Claire and Price.
Early morning. Price lathers up with shaving cream for th first time, cleaning up. As he applies the lather he stop and slowly draws a face on the mirror with shaving cream  until he is staring at:

head_text.subj: THE IMAGE OF RAFAEL IN SHAVING CREAM ON THE MIRROR

text: A RENTED CAR WITH WHITE FLAGS turns onto the road to Leon Price drives, eats, and reads a map. Claire takes the map from him and reads it herself. They seem to enjoy their f moment alone without Alex looking over their shoulder. A  small band-aid is on Price's clean shaven cheek.
Did you dream about Miss Panama last  night?
I dreamed about you.
Have a good time?
Yeah... so'd you.
She reaches out and touches his band-aid.
And old war injury flaring up?
Is the tape on?
Of course.

I was on the deck of the U.S.S. Pueblo  catching some rays when the North  Koreans attacked... took a bullet  right in the chest, but by luck I  had an extra roll of high speed  ektachrome in this pocket right  here... over the heart...
And the bullet ricocheted off the  film, grazed your cheek, and saved  your life.
You heard about it?! I was lucky.
PASSING SHOT OF A CLUSTER OF ROADSIDE CROSSES marking a s of graves. Immediately the tone in Claire's voice changes sobered by the reminder of war.
Did anyone ever die next to you in  combat?
Yeah.
What did you do?
F.8 at a sixtieth.
That's an old joke. My question was  serious.
So was I. (beat) You ever dream about me?
Once.
How was I?
Fast.

Again their glibness is interrupted by what they came to  see. Even as they joke, they watch the landscape with con REFUGEES ARE STREAMING OUT OF LEON, mostly women and chil some old men, carrying their possessions. Soldiers stand  around.
I'm basically a coward, Russell, I  hope you understand that. I hope we  don't get shot.
Me too.

head_text.subj: A GUARDIA ROADBLOCK ON A HILL OVERLOOKING THE CITY

text: The press car pulls up to a stop. Price and Claire get ou quickly, hand their credentials to a soldier, and open th trunk and the hood. As the car is searched they look down the city.
from several places in the town. The sound of gunfire.
(to soldier in Spanish) I thought it was quiet here.
(in Spanish) Quiet? Are you sure you want to go  down there? Not me.
The soldier laughs at the journalists and hands back the  credentials.
(in Spanish) You must leave the car here.
Price speaks in English knowing he can't be understood.
(to soldier) You thinking of scoring a Toyota?
(in Spanish) No problem -- we leave the car.

Price and Claire remove their things from the car, and Pr takes the distributor cap as well as the keys. They walk  over and look down the road leading into the city under s MORE REFUGEES EVACUATE THE TOWN -- it is a most uninvitin sight. The plane passes over the town in the distance fir rockets.
Now what?
Price responds by flashing his light meter in the air, ta a quick, nervous reading.
C'mon. Be careful.
Be careful?! Where the fuck we going?  Better light?

head_text.subj: PRICE AND CLAIRE WALK SLOWLY INTO LEON

text: Looking around warily as they go, they are the only peopl entering the town. Claire speaks softly into her tape rec as they walk in, recording the event without editorializi
...June tenth... the evacuation of  Leon... a woman carries a pig...  signs for the F.S.L.N. are  everywhere... a body...
THE BODY OF A YOUNG MAN lies ignored on the sidewalk. The continue walking and soon come to:

head_text.subj: AN INTERSECTION HELD BY LA GUARDIA TROOPS WITH A TANQUETT

text: Price and Claire duck into a doorway, protected in effect the Government soldiers who wait silently, guns ready, ar the corner of a building. We see what they're waiting for A YOUNG SANDINISTA COMES OUT OF A BUILDING a block away,  holding a handgun. Momentarily confused, he begins runnin toward us, toward the soldiers waiting in ambush. The  Guerrilla races quickly to his waiting death, and as he t the corner right into a dozen Guardia troops: THE GUARDIA GUNS OPEN UP ON THE YOUNG GUERRILLA, killing instantly. CLAIRE TURNS HER HEAD AWAY unable to watch.

head_text.subj: PRICE RECORDS THE EVENT WITH HIS CAMERA

text: THE GUARDIA FOLLOW THE TANQUETTA SLOWLY down the street t the Rebel youth's house. Suddenly the intersection is emp PRICE AND CLAIRE MOVE DOWN A SIDESTREET SLOWLY as: SEVERAL GUERRILLA MUCHACHOS DART OUT OF AN ALLEY with  sharpened sticks, a spear gun, and one home-made gun. The Muchachos hesitate briefly, lost, and see Price. THE MUCHACHOS QUICKLY POSE FOR A PICTURE motioning for Pr to record them. They pose instantly in "tough-guy" postur PRICE TAKES THEIR PICTURE and just as quickly they dart a through a bombed out building. THREE SANDINISTAS LEAP OFF A ROOFTOP and race toward Clai and Price who freeze:
Russell?!

For a moment they aren't sure what this means -- are they trouble? The Sandinistas shove past the two journalists,  pushing open a doorway and disappearing inside. For a mom Price and Claire are alone on the street. THE DOOR OPENS AGAIN SLOWLY and a middle-aged WOMAN appea motioning for them to come inside.
The Three Sandinistas, dressed half in khaki, half recycl disco, are pleading with a young man, PEDRO, 15.
(in Spanish) You must come and help us... one  more time.
(in Spanish) No, please...
One of the Sandinistas brings Pedro his rumpled baseball  jersey from another room.
(in Spanish) For Leon... for Nicaragua!
Pedro sees Price and Claire and is more interested in the He speaks in broken but understandable English.
Americans? Journalists?
Yes.
Pedro lights up, and runs to a shelf where he returns wit baseball he is signing.
Ah! I put my autograph on this ball.
(in Spanish) Pedro! There is no time to waste.
Pedro is more interested in the two Americans.
When you get back to the United  States, I want you to give this ball  to Tippy Martinez for me. He is from  Nicaragua.

Pedro hands Claire the baseball as the Sandinistas plead  with Pedro for his help. He is more interested in getting the baseball delivered to Tippy Martinez. Claire accepts ball graciously, exchanges awkward glances with Price, an puts it in her shoulder bag.
(in Spanish) Enrique is dead! Roberto has  disappeared! The Guardia has the  church, and we need you!
(to Claire and Price) You come, eh? (to the Sandinistas) Can they come with us?
Come! Everybody come!

They go to the door and open it a crack to look out. P.O.V. THE TANQUETTA PASSES as Soldiers kick open doors a the street. The Sandinistas go to a corner of the room and push a boo shelf out of the way. A large hole has been broken in the wall. They climb through the hole into the living room of the next house; the woman pushes the shelf back over the  hole with great effort.
A family huddles in the corner as the MAN OF THE HOUSE pu back a couch and a hanging blanket, revealing another hol knocked in the wall. The Sandinistas, Pedro, Claire and P scramble through.
all the houses on the block, connecting the homes with a  secret passageway. The six of them race through the house each hole opening and then closing magically.

location: THE KITCHEN OF A TINY SIDEWALK RESTAURANT

text: The Three Sandinistas, Pedro, Claire, and Price emerge. A WOMAN, 50, runs the cafe and welcomes them. The SIX crawl as not to be seen from the street; they stop long enough survey the plaza.

Half a dozen bodies are scattered across the plaza. Other it is empty. P.O.V. SIX GUARDIA SNIPERS IN THE CHURCH TOWER control th plaza. As we watch, they fire off occasional shots in  different directions--there is no way to cross the plaza. THE WOMAN PULLS A TRAY OF "CONTACT BOMBS" from the oven,  home-made grenades that look like muffins on a tray. Pedr grabs one and pretends to bite into it. The Sandinistas s to laugh and catch themselves as Pedro clowns. Claire and Price aren't sure what the "muffins" are and don't respon mostly they are on edge. The contact bombs are put in a s The woman opens a trap door in the floor, and the six of  them climb down a ladder into a tunnel.
Pedro leads them with a candle through a dark passage und the street. Overhead we hear gunfire. Rats scurry, and wa runs through an open sewer.

A tapestry rug is pulled away, and Pedro's head appears. climbs out and soon all the party is in the church. A PRI leads them quickly through an immense, nearly. European  interior of ornate altars and burning candles. The small  party is led to a small corner of the sanctuary where a l rickety ladder leads up to the roof. THE SANDINISTAS SCRAMBLE UP THE LADDER as it sways. Pedro follows with his sack of contact bombs. Then Price goes u as the Priest holds the ladder. The American is much larg than the Nicaraguans -- the ladder squeaks and sways, and when he is nearly at the top: THE LADDER CRACKS as Price reaches the top and is helped safety. The Priest steadies the ladder now made unsafe an clearly Claire wants to go onto the roof.
(in Spanish) No, please... it's not safe. You  must come with me.
Claire looks at Price -- she wants to go on the roof but sound of close gunfire settles the dilemma. Claire hurrie off to safety with the Priest.

location: THE ROOFTOP OF THE CATHEDRAL OF LEON

head_text.subj: THREE SANDINISTAS, PEDRO, AND PRICE EMERGE FROM A TUNNEL

text: onto a lower level of the cathedral rooftop where a body  lies. They are exposed immediately and automatic weapons  fire opens up on them -- the Sandinistas flatten against wall, quickly becoming separated from Price and Pedro. TWO SANDINISTAS RACE FOR COVER BEHIND A CUPOLA in a move  that is equally daring and foolish. The diversion draws f from the two soldiers. PRICE'S LIGHT METER IS INSTANTLY OUT TAKING READINGS as P huddles with him, curious at this strange act.

head_text.subj: TWO GUARDIA MOVE INTO POSITION TO FLUSH OUT THE SANDINIST

text: as they hide behind the cupolas. The hidden Third Guerril opens fire killing a Guardia soldier, and the other soldi races for the belltower. As he does: THE SANDINISTAS SEIZE THE MOMENT TO RUSH CLOSER, waving t Pedro who slips along a wall with his bag of bombs. PRICE STARTS TO FOLLOW BUT IS PINNED DOWN BY FIRE and cho to take refuge halfway in an alcove. As fire from both si ricochets all over the rooftop, Price switches camera len seemingly oblivious to the action. PEDRO MEETS ONE OF THE SANDINISTAS in a protected niche a quickly they are unfolding his bag, setting the "muffin b out on the rooftop. THE OTHER TWO SANDINISTAS OPEN HEAVY FIRE and briefly dra heavier fire from the belltower, as: PEDRO PICKS UP A MUFFIN weighing it briefly in his hand,  like a pitcher. He studies the surroundings -- runners on first and third, no outs -- he spits in his left (his pit hand) and rubs it in casually. Pedro crosses himself, goes into an abbreviated pitching  motion, then rears and fires the 'muffin' toward the bell window, exposing himself as he does.

head_text.subj: AN EXPLOSION IN THE TOWER

text: PEDRO THROWS ANOTHER INTO THE TOWER -- another explosion. A GUARDIA SOLDIER STAGGERS INTO THE WINDOW and a Sandinis drops him with a shot. All is quiet. THE THREE SANDINISTAS CAREFULLY RUSH THE TOWER, looking i and motion to Pedro and Price that all is okay, and as th do: ANOTHER SHOT RINGS OUT -- they whirl around -- Pedro and  Price drop again. A lone Guardia soldier fires at them fr the other tower. A THIRD SANDINISTA DROPS HIM WITH A VOLLEY OF FIRE Again is quiet. PRICE FOLLOWS THE SANDINISTAS TO THE FIRST BELLTOWER and  looks in. FIVE BODIES LIE SCATTERED AND BLOODIED One of the Guerril kicks a couple of them to make sure they are dead. In the corner, one body lies on top of another. Satisfied, the  Sandinistas head for the other tower. PRICE STAYS BEHIND TO TAKE A FEW PICTURES and the ever-pr light meter appears, followed by several quick shots of t bodies. Then Price goes to one of the arched, stone windo He looks out over the city. P.O.V. OF LEON -- DUSK Late in the afternoon now, the fig is over for the day. An occasional gunshot. Smoke rises f scattered places throughout the city. There is new rubble The town is littered with bodies.
A man walks in front of it, chanting slowly, rhythmically
Hay heridas o muertes aqui? Hay  heridas o muertes aqui? (Are there wounded or  dead here?)
We see a woman drag a body out into the street. The Red C man makes small stacks of bodies. He douses the bodies wi gasoline and sets the pile aflame. Then continues.
Hay heridas o muertes aqui?
Price watches. He thinks he hears something, then dismiss it. Something else. A voice, almost a whisper.
Price. You motherfucker, Price, I'm  talking to you.
He turns. One of the bodies speaks.
Where are those bastards... are they  away?
Price looks out -- the Sandinistas are on the other side the roof. This war gets stranger.
They're away.

A body rolls out from under another body. Blood-splattere smiling, wiping the blood from his face. It is Oates, the mercenary from Africa. He peeks out the window -- the  Sandinistas are on the other side of the roof. He whisper
What the fuck are you doing here?
What the fuck are you doing here?
For a moment they understand that they are there for the  same reason -- they make their livings off war. Oates pee out the window nervously and repeatedly.
Awright, awright -- you're lookin'  good... how ya like Nicaragua?
OATES readies his automatic weapon in case it's needed -- routine. Price doesn't know how to answer.
It's beautiful.
Oates laughs quickly and softly -- he is tuned into the  strangeness of Price's answer.
Shitload o' greasers though, eh?
OATES AND PRICE SEE THEM, and Oates crawls back under the pile of bodies. THE SANDINISTAS LOOK INTO THE BELLTOWER, all looks quiet, and they motion to Price.
(in Spanish) It's getting late -- come on.

The Three Sandinistas, Pedro, and Price are hiding in the shadows of the main church entrance. The Sandinistas are  carefully peeking around the corner, checking out the pla It seems safe. The door opens; the Priest lets Claire out For a moment she looks around to see who's still alive -- the shadows Price looks like one of the Guerrillas. They each other and embrace briefly.
You're okay?
The Sandinistas seem to relax. The Sandinistas take pride Pedro and pat his left arm for Price and Claire.
San-dee Koufax, no?
Si, Koufax.
Es mejor que Koufax, eh?!
They seem to want approval from the Americans.
Much better than Koufax.

The Sandinistas slap hands, familiar with the American  gesture. The Six start walking across the plaza away from the church. In the b.g. we see piles of bodies burning; t Red Cross tends to the wounded locals. Spirits are high a they walk. The tiny red light glows on Claire's recorder.
Koufax is okay... but Tippy Martinez,  he is the best... he pitches for the  Baltimore Orioles, and some day I  will be the second man from Nicaragua  to play in the major leagues...
(to Price and Claire) Tippy Martinez had a good fastball,  but Pedro has a curveball and a  screwball that are better.
All five of them agree that Pedro is the best; they slap valued arm and relax for the first time all day.
You will give my autographed baseball  to Tippy and tell him in five years  I will be pitching with him, okay?  He better watch out for me, eh?
OATES CHECKS THE CLIP ON HIS RIFLE and looks down into th plaza. OATES P.O.V. TO THE SIX WALKING AWAY He doesn't smile or  joke -- it's all business. He aims the rifle.
(in Spanish) It's too dangerous to return to  Managua at night. You should stay at  the house of hammocks.
(in Spanish) Gracias. Can they get into trouble  for keeping us?
No, no... you are not combatants. (would rather talk  baseball) The Baltimore team is my team...

A SHOT RINGS OUT, AND PEDRO'S CHEST EXPLODES in front of Sudden panic, rage, confusion -- the Sandinistas whirl an scan the building. P.O.V. OATES RACING ACROSS THE CATHEDRAL ROOFTOP into the night. PRICE GRABS PEDRO'S GUN AND WHIRLS to face the church; hi action is instinctive, angry, and electric with energy. CLAIRE GRABS PEDRO'S ARM AND DRAGS THE BODY to safety, th there is no safety and the body is lifeless. Her actions protective and automatic. THE SANDINISTAS TAKE CONTROL OF THE SITUATION and move  quickly. Two of them fan out to cover the escape. Price  screams in the direction of Oates,
You bastard!
Claire drags the body near a bench under a tree.
What about him?!
(dispassionately) He's dead.
The Sandinistas survey the cathedral and streets carefull warily, upset at their nonchalance. They know the sniper disappearing into the night, but they continue to look.
I will talk to Pedro's mother. You  must go to the house of the hammocks  if you want to be safe.

The Three Sandinistas fan out toward the church as it get dark. PRICE AND CLAIRE STAND NEXT TO PEDRO, feeling helpless an ineffective. They both look at the body. Price realizes h holding Pedro's gun and places it down next to the body.  Price notices the tiny red light is still glowing on her  tape recorder. He points it out to Claire. She turns it o

IN A NEARLY DARK ROOM full of hanging hammocks, Claire si on the floor lit by a low wattage bulb hanging from a cor In another room through a door Price can be seen with a f in the hammock workshop. Claire talks softly into her  recorder.

Hello sweetheart, this is your mother.  I'm in Leon and I miss you. Don't  worry about me -- it's not dangerous  at all. I guess you can't believe  what you hear on the news. I'll put  this this tape in the mail when I  get back to Managua, but knowing  what the mail service is like, I may  be home before it arrives. I think  about you all the time and hope I  can make it back before you graduate  from Jr. High.
As she speaks Price bids the family farewell and comes in the room with Claire where he lies down in a hammock.
I love you and I'll finish this letter  when I get back to the hotel.
Claire lies down on a mat, exhausted, after turning out t light. Several moments pass before Price speaks.
I know who shot Pedro. I knew somebody  was in the tower.
Why didn't you tell the guerrillas?
I don't know... then they would've  killed him I guess. I didn't want to  interfere.
It wasn't an easy choice.
I think I made the wrong one.
Silence.
You didn't take any pictures when it  was over.
I didn't? (beat) I picked up a gun. Jesus. (beat) Is something happening to us?
Yes.
Silence. They lie for a long time in the dark. A light in the house is turned off. Finally:
Are you asleep?
No.
Price gets out of the hammock and lies down next to her.  They don't speak. They kiss. She unbuttons his shirt. He  unbuttons her blouse. They undress just enough to begin m love softly, quietly.

The first light of dawn strikes Claire's bare torso. PRICE'S LIGHT METER APPEARS AT HER BACK Price takes a rea then moves the meter to her neck, another reading. He mov it down her nude body lit beautifully in the vague light, partially covered with a blanket. He scurries across the room, stark naked, with a camera.  Price begins photographing her. He moves back to her and gently removes the blanket from rest of her body. His actions are quiet and easy. He stop frequently to admire her. Claire lies sleeping nude, except for her socks. Price mo around the room -- picture, picture, picture. CLAIRE WAKES UP SLOWLY and pulls the blanket back over he She opens her eyes and sees Price sitting in a chair seve feet away with his camera.
G'morning.
What are you doing?
You look beautiful.
She realizes what he's been doing.
How long have you been doing this?
'Bout ten frames. Wait'll you see  the pictures -- you look great.
Her sense of violation is balanced by this notion. For a  moment we sense her attitude can go either way -- outrage some sense of being flattered, however ill conceived. She chooses the latter.
I'll bet I look great -- give me the  film.
After they're printed.
I'll develop them myself -- give it  to me or I'll start taping what you  say in your sleep.
Price hands her the film and climbs back under the blanke with her.
I talk in my sleep?
Girl's names and F-stops. Terrible.
They curl up together, holding onto each other. A small c crosses the courtyard, peeking at them. A rooster crows.
Call the office. I don't want to go  to work today.
The peacefulness is shaken by the roar of an engine close by. A HELICOPTER GUNSHIP PASSES OVER THE COURTYARD They look jolted out of the moment. The war is back.

Price's rental car is a smoking wreck. He and Claire arri and she removes a single, feeble white flag that remains. They study the car briefly and then turn as: A GUARDIA TROOP CARRIER LUMBERS past with a truckload of  refugees behind. They wave the flag and catch a ride with the refugees.
Alex comes out a door chatting with somebody, and passes mini-cam crew, old friends.
How was Matagalpa?
No bang-bang, Alex... none at all.
You find anything?
Half the press corps.
A small laugh. They continue on. Alex enters Claire's roo

Alex enters. Nobody there. As he turns to leave he sees s pictures in a stack of papers on her desk. He picks one u CLOSE UP: A PICTURE OF CLAIRE SLEEPING IN LEON It's all o and he knows it. He stares at, even admires, the image. H puts it down and turns to leave as:

head_text.subj: CLAIRE ENTERS

text: Oh!
Oh. (awkwardly) How was Leon?
Bloody.
Yeah... I'll bet... Claire...
Alex finally acknowledges that it is over with Claire, bu refuses to say it directly.
I'm tired of Nicaragua.
You haven't been here very long.
Long enough, lets face it, you were  right... everybody was right.
About what?
My cheekbones. What do you think of  'em?
I like your cheekbones. Alex, are  you all right?
This is a face made for television.
You decided to go with the network.
Alex nods, then seems to hit the end of his own resilienc and gets vitriolic.
Is he a good fuck?
Alex...
In a simple monologue Alex goes from outrage to acknowled of what he already knew.

That's a reasonable question for a  reporter to ask, isn't it?! (beat) I shoulda never come down here, eh?  This is the way it's going to be. (beat) I'll make a shitload of money in  television for just sitting there. (beat) I'm gonna show up to work at  Rockefeller Center every morning and  they're gonna hand me the news with  my coffee and toast. (beat) I shoulda never come down here, eh?  This war down here belongs to you  guys, okay? I'm on tommorrow's plane.
Alex...
You want to take me to the airport?  It's okay. (beat -- resigned) I shoulda never come down here.
A cab pulls up. Soldiers stand around everywhere. Price,  Claire, Alex, and the Cabbie get out. The cabbie takes hi bag.
Take this to check in. I'll be right  there.
Price pulls a bottle of wine from his camera bag and sets three styrofoam cups on the cab roof. He hands the cork t Alex and shows him the label.
Sniff this sucker, eh?
Alex does, and looks at the label.
Jesus, where'd you get this?
The C.I.A.
Where else.
They toast and drink.
Hey -- I'll leave you guys alone,  eh?
No, no, don't be ridiculous.
We're grownups, Russell... (non acerbically) Most of us.
Awkward smile from Price.
You two wanta happy snap?
Price makes the motion of taking a picture. They look at with affection, yet astounded again by his inappropriaten
No happy snaps.
Okay, okay... (beat) I'll just... be over here.

He wanders away from the car to give them a moment alone, and as he does he pulls the light meter from his pocket,  flipping it on and off nervously without looking at it. H wanders idly toward a Guardia soldier. The soldier gets  nervous.
You're sure about him?
For the moment.
Alex considers this -- he understands (whether he wants t or not). THE SOLDIER COMES FACE-TO-FACE with PRICE, WHO BACKS OFF
(to soldier) I'm a personal friend of Tacho's. (smiles disarmingly)
The soldier stops at Tacho's name. Price turns.
PRICE TURNS AGAIN, embarrassed, faces the soldier.
Don't look, huh? (beat) No mire!
The soldier, confused, turns away, and as he does:

head_text.subj: ALEX SLAPS PRICE ON THE SHOULDER, AND THEY TOO EMBRACE

text: Don't get hurt.
Ahh, I'm a chicken, don't worry. (beat) Alex, listen to me...
Yeah?
Within a year you're gonna be one of  the "Ten Most Admired Men in America."
Alex is amused, Price is serious. The cabbie comes out an Alex heads into the airport.

Daisy and her combo from the Viking Club perform "The Gir From Ipanema" as ONE HUNDRED PRESS MEMBERS and V.I.P.'s s at long tables in the garden. The pleasantness of the  surroundings is countered by the presence of dozens of  SOLDIERS in the background, guarding the house, etc. Visi at the head table are: TWO GENERALS AND THEIR WIVES, MRS.
HAT. Elsewhere mingling are: JAZY, ISELA, PRICE, REGIS. A elaborate array of food sits on the table.
Overlooking the gathering from his private living room, S grants Claire her interview. He close the window to muffl the singing.
You're late to your own luncheon,  Mr. President -- we can schedule  this for another time.
Nonsense -- let them wait. We are a  stunning couple, eh? My stomach is  very flat -- I've been working out.
We are a stunning couple. Mr.  President, you own one fifth of all  the land in Nicaragua, you own the  shipping port, the national airlines,  the Mercedes dealership...
I am on a salt free diet...
He takes her hand and leads her to two large portraits ha on a wall -- his parents.
Do you always hold hands with  reporters?
(ignores her) This is my mother and father. They  were very special to me. Every Sunday  morning I drive out to the cemetery  and put flowers on their grave. I  think people should know that.
Would you care to comment on the  fall of Leon to the rebels?
Somoza just smiles unaffected by her questions; she knows the game is undaunted.
Hub Kittle is bending Price's ear in the crowd. Price see ammused and watches the anthem contest as he munches food

Listen, Russell, let's grow up. It's  very easy to fall in love with the  underdog, eh? But there's an upside  and downside to this thing -- just  wanta remind you... this stuff about  a "Revolution of Poets" is crap.
But it's great P.R. So what's the  upside?

Simple. And it could happen. Somoza  destroys the terrorist insurgents,  rebuilds the country, shitcans the  purveyors of excess, stabilizes the  cordoba, and is finally beloved as  the savior of Nicaragua. (beat) Our pal. Got a smoke?
Price gives him a cigaret.
What's the downside?
The Commies take over the world.

It's simple, and Hub is pleased with his presentation. A  SOLDIER moves through the crowd looking quite out of plac finds Hub and hands him a note. Hub reads it, seems delig and excuses himself from the table.
Excuse me, gentlemen, but the war  may be over.
Price and Regis look at each other strangely -- what's he talking about? They shrug, Regis bites into a papaya, and Hub hurries inside. Price and Regis watch the singer.
My people love me. My stomach is  flat. Did I say that already? No  matter. It is flat.
There are reports that the Guardia  operates a torture chamber at  Coyotepe.
Somoza ignores the question and reopens the window, flood the room with the Tony Bennett classic.
I like this song.

Since the earthquake in 1972 destroyed  half of Managua, over three hundred  million dollars in foreign relief  aid have poured into the country,  yet nothing has been re-built. It is  said that the money has gone into  your pocket.
I love the press, I really do. Some  of my best friends are journalists.
Ecuador, Mexico, Peru, Brazil, and  Panama are reportedly on the verge  of breaking off diplomatic relations  with your regime. Would you comment?
HUB KITTLE AND AN OFFICER BURST INTO THE ROOM interruptin the interview. Something has happened. Somoza initially l out at them -- the first time we've seen him lose his coo then recovers.
(in Spanish) I am busy! Get out of here at once  or I'll put my foot up your ass!
The OFFICER seems familiar with these tirades and grabs S by the arm, whispering into his ear. Somoza seems delight with the news and turns to Hub for confirmation. Hub nods
(to Claire) I'm sorry to have to conclude this  most pleasant encounter, but something  has happened.
As Somoza leaves the room with the Officer and Hub, Hub t to Claire to squeeze in one final P.R. stroke.
Did he tell you about his parents in  the graveyard, the flowers and all  that? (she nods) Good, good...
Claire is left alone momentarily in Somoza's room. A sold enters and accompanies her outside to the luncheon.

As Claire comes outside, there is a flurry of activity at the head table. TWO OFFICERS hastily set up an easel with large military-topographical map of Nicaragua. A SOLDIER  takes the microphone from the Singers -- the music grinds an inglorious halt -- and carries it to the head table. Price spots Claire and makes a "What's all this about?"  motion.
