Claire holds out her palms and shrugs -- she does know. All attention is quickly focused on the head table, as: PRESIDENT SOMOZA MAKES A GRAND ENTRANCE FLANKED by Hub Ki and an Officer. He seems suddenly in unusually good spiri Hub taps the mike -- it works -- he motions for Somoza to come forward.
My friends... this gathering was not  intended to be a press conference as  much as a... "get-together"... but I  have just been handed a piece of  news.
Somoza plays the moment with theatrical elan.
Rafael is dead. (beat) He has been killed in an ambush in  the Cordillera mountains of the  Jinotega district.
Somoza points to a spot on the map as do his Officer. THE PRESS TABLE IS SHAKEN FROM ITS NONCHALANCE and severa journalists immediately leap to their feet to question hi
Mr. President! Mr. President!
Please my friends -- no questions. A  press release is being prepared.

Somoza hands the mike to an aide who returns it to the mu stand. Almost immediately the music begins again. AT THE PRESS TABLE there is some confusion over the  announcement. Some journalists hurry off to file the stor others just sit. Price seems alarmed by the announcement, confused. Slightly wired, he listens to Regis and OTHER  JOURNALIST discuss it.
They got Rafael? You believe that?
Every six months Tacho gives this  speech -- maybe they finally lucked  out.

CLAIRE TRIES TO CORNER HUB KITTLE who is heading back ins Hub disappears inside, Claire pressing after him. JAZY APPROACHES PRICE and leans in as if sharing a confid IN the b.g. the luncheon is breaking up.
Russell, excuse me... but I've just  been put in a rather embarrassing  position. (hesitates) Mrs. Somoza would like her picture  taken with Miss Panama. In color?
Price throws his camera bag over his shoulder, pulls out camera, and follows Jazy. They walk toward the head table
How the hell could Tacho find Rafael.
Russell, please... I have my hands  full...
Mrs. Somoza and Miss Panama are waiting as Price and Jazy arrive. Price is automatically switching camera lenses, b he continues to grill Jazy.
Tacho, Tacho... venga, por favor!

Price and Jazy exchange glances as Somoza reluctantly joi the portrait. SOMOZA POSES WITH HIS WIFE AND HIS MISTRESS ON EACH ARM a Price flashes a light meter under their noses, then backs off to take the picture.
Is Tacho lying again? They did kill  him, didn't they?
Everybody smile.
Price takes a picture, Somoza wants to leave and Jazy wou just as soon have this awkward moment over with, but:
One more, please! Una mas, por favor?
Reluctantly they pose again, and Price grills Jazy who is trapped.
We help each other, right? Could you  move your girlfriend into the sun...
Jazy moves Miss Panama slightly, returning to Price.
What do you need?
Is Rafael alive or dead?
I don't know.
(to the posers) Just one more -- thank you. (to Jazy) I thought you knew everything?
As Somoza holds an interminable pose, Jazy launches into speech, keeping his voice low enough so Tacho cannot hear
What do I know, eh? Tacho needs a  victory very badly... he needs to  prove to Jimmy Carter that he is  still winning. He thinks Rafael's  death is the proof he needs.
Carter don't need proof. He just  sent twenty-five million in new arms  to Tacho. (to posers) I'm sorry... almost got it here.
No, no... the arms shipment has been  delayed in New Orleans because Jimmy  is getting nervous.
The State Department's gonna pull  the plug on Tacho?! Pardon my French --  but whose fucking side are you on?
Jazy and Price motion for the posers to move a step over.
...I work for everybody. If there is  a transition of power, I facilitate  a relationship with the new people.  If there is not, I facilitate the  status quo. (beat) Either way, I facilitate.
Great job.
I send messages to Jimmy and I tell  him that the Revolution is a flood  that cannot be stopped but it can be  controlled... nobody listens... I  can't even get a little water in my  pool.
Rough ain't it. Thank you everybody,  very nice.
Price smiles to Somoza, Mrs. Somoza, and Miss Panama. Som hurries off from his uncomfortable position at last.
I don't think Rafael is dead. I'm  gonna find him.
They say he's very handsome. (beat) It would make a wonderful picture,  eh?
The two men share a smile.
A rental station wagon covered with press flags races alo Inside the car are the British crew -- Regis drives -- an Price and Claire.

A city of about 50,000 located on the side of a hill. The car pulls slowly into the base of the town into a clearin with assorted vehicles -- Red Cross, La Guardia, Press. T car moves slowly as its occupants survey the town, until pulls alongside a Red Cross truck that has broken down. P sticks his head out the window to ask instructions of a R WORKER.
Con permiso -- who controls what  today?
(in Spanish) The Sandinistas hold the hills, the  Guardia has everything else.
How do we find the guerillas?
(points) Va alli, dos o tres cuartos, doble  la esquina al francotirador.
What'd he say?
Go two or three blocks and turn right  at the sniper.
Regis and his crew don't like this at all. Price points.
You can drop us off.

head_text.subj: MAIN ROAD INTO MATAGALPA

text: A gradual uphill grade -- the press car moves slowly. Gua are on both sides of the street, as the car stops at the  corner, directly beneath the sniper tower. They all look

head_text.subj: THE CAR SLOWLY TURNS LEFT

text: Wrong way!
We're not looking for the guerillas.
Then let us out.
The car stops, the door opens, and:

head_text.subj: A WALL NEARBY IS RIDDLED WITH BULLET HOLES AS THEY CLIMB

text: OUT, so they climb back in quickly. P.O.V. A SOLDIER HOLDS OUT HIS ARMS AS IF TO SAY, "accide
Lo siento! (I'm sorry!)
The soldier seems sincere, but they don't want to take a  chance.
Go one more block.

THE CAR MOVES DEEPER INTO MATAGALPA, gradually moving amo tanquettas patrolling the streets, coming to a barricade  which they manuever past as Guardia soldiers look at them strangely. The car turns around -- it has come too far. A GUARDIA OFFICER SIGNALS FOR THEM TO GET OUT but the ide doesn't appeal to Regis and he whirls around, panicking  slightly, and heads off in the other direction.
He just wanted to see credentials,  for crissakes, what're doing?
You want to drive?
We want out!
THE BARRICADE OFFICER SPEAKS IN A WALKIE TALKIE to a squa leader a couple of blocks away as the car approaches. THE SECOND OFFICER WHISTLES FOR THE CAR TO STOP but it sp up.

head_text.subj: WINDSHIELD
INSIDE THE CAR

text: GLASS and Regis panics, hitting the floorboard and the ca suddenly screeches around a corner, racing through Mataga The car squeals around corner after corner blindly, into:

head_text.subj: A GUARDIA BARRICADE AS A FUSILADE OF SMALL ARMS FIRE RING

text: OUT The windshield is totally destroyed now, and: THE OCCUPANTS OF THE CAR CROUCH LOW as the car races. Pri and Claire scream at Regis to stop, but it's too late. THE CAR SCREECHES INTO REVERSE as Regis tries to see out back window and Price, out of necessity operates the foot pedal with his hand. The car smokes into an intersection sees: AN OPEN BLOCK AHEAD -- no Guardia are visible, so the car races down the open block and as it comes to an intersect

head_text.subj: A SHERMAN TANK COMES AROUND THE CORNER FACING US

text: Several times larger than a tanquetta -- it dwarfs us and everything around it. Its giant gun faces us head on. THE PRESS CAR SCREECHES TO A HALT, and everyone scrambles out.
Periodista, periodista, periodista!

The mini-cam equipment is dropped as the British crew  scrambles to safety against a building. Price and Claire up on opposite sides of the street. Silence -- the huge and silent tank is deciding what to d THE TURRET SWINGS SEVERAL DEGREES TO ONE SIDE and lowers the scattered journalists freeze.

head_text.subj: A THUNDEROUS ROAR

text: leaving a huge crater and not a trace of the expensive qe CLAIRE STARTS LAUGHING, FRIGHTENED, nervous and amused.

head_text.subj: PRICE TAKES PICTURES
A WOMAN THROWS A CONTACT BOMB FROM A WINDOW AT THE TANK T

text: tiny bomb makes a pitiful explosion, hopelessly ineffecti

head_text.subj: THE TANK SWINGS ITS TURRET TOWARD THE HOUSE AND OPENS FIR

text: and the wall of the house crumbles quickly as a family  scrambles to the rooftop of a neighboring house. Their ho is destroyed in a second. LA GUARDIA TROOPS APPEAR AND BEGIN FIRING TOWARDS Claire Price, who turn to see: SANDINISTA ARMY REGULARS RUNNING DOWN THE HILL alongside homemade local guerillas. This is the first time we've se the F.S.L.N. regular army in their camouflaged khaki dres THE GUARD TAKES A POSITION TO FIGHT IT OUT and Claire and Price are caught in a cross-fire, pinned to walls on each street side. PRICE PUSHES THROUGH A DOOR TO SAFETY and looks back: CLAIRE IS TRAPPED OUTSIDE pounding on a door that doesn't open. She tries another -- no luck. She curls up in a doo making herself as small as possible as bullets rip the wa around her.

head_text.subj: AT THE TOP OF THE HILL, AN OLD BUS MOVES SLOWLY INTO THE
STREET

text: Several youthful guerillas are pushing it. THE BUS COMES FLYING DOWN THE HILL TOWARD THE TANK Severa hundred feet away, it gathers speed toward us.

A YOUTH at the wheel props a board under the steering whe and races to the back as ANOTHER YOUTH opens the door as bus races past Claire toward the tank. THE TWO YOUTHS LEAP OUT THE BACK DOOR where they tumble i the dirt just before:

head_text.subj: THE BUS SMASHES INTO THE TANK AND EXPLODES

text: GUARDIA SOLDIERS SHOOT THE TWO YOUTHS before they get awa as: GUERILLAS APPEAR ON EVERY ROOFTOP opening heavy fire on L Guardia.

head_text.subj: GUARDIA TROOPS RETREAT QUICKLY ON FOOT AND IN TANQUETTAS

text: THE SHERMAN TANK TRIES TO DISLODGE ITSELF FROM THE BUS bu cannot, and drags the bus with it as it backs down the hi PRICE RUNS OUT TO CLAIRE and huddles with her. She is sha but unhurt. SANDINISTAS ARE EVERYWHERE, moving into Matagalpa as Pric and Claire move past several bodies to higher ground. SANDINISTA BARRICADES ARE ON EVERY CORNER where women ser food to their men. Claire and Price wander through,  momentarily disoriented. A small boy runs through the str kicking a soccer ball, occasionally avoiding a body. He r right up to them and speaks.
Busca triquitraques?
Si.
Venga.
They follow him up a hill.
THE NEIGHBORHOOD IS TOTALLY SANDINISTA and several gueril are at the door. The boy speaks to one of the guards, and they are admitted.

THEY ARE SEARCHED IMMEDIATELY, asked to put down their ge asked for credentials, and led down the hallway of a hous that is very American middle class. ANOTHER SOLDIER WITH RIFLE detains them momentarily befor showing them into a room used as a Revolutionary Command  office. ISELA STANDS IN MILITARY FATIGUES talking to her Sandinis colleagues. Clearly she commands respect and makes decisi She finishes and turns to Claire and Price in a very  businesslike way, never acknowledging directly that they  have met before.
You are looking for Rafael?
They are somewhat taken aback at her directness and  information.
Yeah. If it's possible.
Do you know why we're here... exactly?
Mr. Price doesn't do anything before  announcing it first in the bar. (beat) It's a good story. You'll be more  famous.

An old truck chugs up a series of cutbacks through rough  terrain. The truck has no hood, and a BOY sits on the fen pouring oil from a series of Folgers cans into a funnel s permanently into the engine. Underneath, dangling cans ca the oil as it flows through. Price, Claire and FOUR ARMED SANDINISTAS sit in the back. ISELA rides in front.

head_text.subj: THE TRUCK PASSES THROUGH A FRIENDLY GUERILLA ROADBLOCK

text: ISELA, CLAIRE, PRICE AND THE FOUR HIKE into increasingly  inaccessible terrain.

Heavily guarded but very mobile, the camp consists of per 100 Soldiers, women preparing food, several tents. Price Claire attract attention as they enter. PRICE STOPS AND LOOKS AROUND THE CAMP CLOSELY seeming to  take it all in. He's been in many similar camps, countrie wars.
Rafael's tent?
Price doesn't answer but continues taking it all in, and  ISELA shouts to them to continue.
Venga, companeros. (Come, comrades.)
THEY CONTINUE INTO THE CAMP, BUT PRICE STOPS AGAIN Someth has caught him, his sixth sense, a feeling -- he refuses walk further for the moment. No glibness, just coolness.
What is it?
Price looks around, speaks quietly.
Rafael is dead.
Claire looks around quickly. There is no evidence to her.
I can smell it.
I don't know.
(slightly exasperated) Venga por favor! Alli!

They continue into the camp -- now Claire looks around  nervously. Price mutters a half laugh, softly and strange as they are led to a makeshift table and offered food. In the b.g. Isela enters one of the tents. PRICE AND CLAIRE SIT DOWN TO EAT and Price continues scan the camp as they talk.
What're you talking about?
He's dead. I know it.
Then why did they bring us all the  way here to see him?
He doesn't know. P.O.V. FOUR FIGURES/CONFERRING IN FRONT OF A TENT Isela  emerges and joins them. The others are: THE PRIEST FROM L

head_text.subj: A BUSINESSMAN WHOM WE SHOULD RECOGNIZE FROM EARLIER SCENE

text: AND COMMANDANTE CINCO, dressed in camouflaged khaki. ISELA WALKS OVER TO CLAIRE AND PRICE after talking with t others. She brings COMMANDANTE CINCO with her. They sit d
This is Commandante Cinco.
They all shake hands. Isela begins at once.

Today we took Matagalpa. Leon is  about to fall, and Masaya. And next  week we could be in Managua but it  is still possible to lose. (beat) In the last days of our final  offensive the people of Nicaragua  must know that Rafael is alive and  well.
Queremos un fotografia.
We need a photograph. (beat) Come with us.

head_text.subj: THEY ALL RISE AND HEAD TOWARDS RAFAEL'S TENT

text: The tent is filled with Sandinista officers and soldiers  standing and sitting around. RAFAEL'S BODY LIES ON A TABLE The shirtless upper torso  propped slightly upright, still wearing glasses, the figu of Rafael is distinctly non-heroic. He is slightly overwe slightly balding, but as he lies there surrounded by his  men, the the glow of lanterns, he looks almost alive. Price and Claire look at each other.
Usted es un fotografo magnifico. (beat) Queremos que vive. (You are a great  photographer. Make  him alive.)
Price laughs -- the request is ridiculous.
(to Claire) Why is he laughing?
You're crazy.
Cinco steps forward -- his presence commands attention. H delivery is forceful but not emotional. As he begins to s Price stops laughing.

(in Spanish) We have momentum, but many more lives  will be lost. Even Washington is  starting to admit that the butcher  Somoza is not loved by his people.  They have detained twenty-five million  dollars in new arms shipments for  Somoza at an airfield in Florida  until they find out if Rafael is  alive or dead. We know about these  things.
He pauses briefly.
If Washington thinks Rafael is dead,  they will ship the arms to Somoza.  Do you understand.
Yeah. (without enthusiasm) Commandante... Soy un periodista.
CINCO attacks that defense with new vigor.

This has nothing to do with journalism --  there is more to the world than  journalism. We are going to end this  war with you or without you. (beat) People don't really believe in Rafael --  they believe in the idea of Rafael,  no? Because for now the idea of Rafael  is enough for the people of Nicaragua.  When the war is over -- none of this  matters.
PRICE hesitates, his manner devoid of its usual cockiness
I don't do things... like this.
Enough lives have been lost already. (beat of empathy) It's difficult, I know -- but you  must do it.
COMMANDANTE CINCO PLACES AN ARM ON PRICE'S SHOULDER and s in broken English.
In the morning, eh? When there's  better light!

Price lies on his back on a table. Claire sits in a chair lantern is on the table. His reclining body is not unlike Rafael's. He plays with a camera without looking at it,  turning it slowly, removing and replacing a lens. He's ne been this calm, this unmoving. Claire, however, moves around the tent like a caged anima like Price normally is. She smokes. She's nervous and wir
I spend my whole life separating how  I feel from how I think and what I  see from what I say -- that's called  journalism, isn't it?
He nods slightly.

It's disciplined. It civilized. It  involves distinctions. I'm great at  distinctions. I wish I wasn't so  good at them. Sometimes I envy you --  you don't make any -- it's very  convenient. (beat) The only time I don't worry about  all those things is when I'm with my  daughter.
Or when you're in bed.

Yes! (beat -- changes  direction) My job is to find a story, then tell  a story -- whatever it is -- because  I believe that if enough people hear  enough stories then somehow, through  information alone, we all have a  better chance to survive. (beat) I believe in information. (beat) That's a very romantic streak I have  running through me -- maybe it's a  weakness. Information is good --  lack of information is bad. Simple,  eh?
Not so simple.
You're God damn right it's not. (beat) You take that picture you'll take it  for all the right reasons -- I  understand.
I'm not gonna take it.
He fiddles with the cameras.

That's fine for you. But do I go  back and say I interviewed Rafael?  Do I go back and say I missed the  biggest story of the war? Or do I  say Rafael was stone cold dead --  that's the information, isn't it? Or  do I say he entertained us all in  his inimitably charismatic manner  around the ol' revolutionary campfire? (beat) Can we throw up our arms and say we  fell in love with the querillas  because their cause was...  sympathetic? (beat) Journalists don't fall in love. (beat) Which story do you want me to tell?
Silence.
Do what you want to do.
Christ, what the fuck are we doing  here?
I want to be here. (beat) With you. (beat) What do you want.
Silence.
I want this war to end. (beat) I'm not going to tell the world that  Rafael is dead.
Silence. Claire lies down on the cot. Exhausted but high. Price gets off the table and goes to her.
I love you.
I think I love you.
Don't think so much.
He gets on the cot with her. They kiss deeply, passionate and begin making love.

THE CAMP IS COMING TO LIFE as the flap opens on Price's t and he looks out. He raises his camera and starts taking  pictures of: A WOMAN COOKING OVER A FIRE AS A BUSINESSMAN LOOKS ON, a  face we recognize from earlier in Managua -- FREEZE FRAME

head_text.subj: THREE YOUNG GUERRILLAS PLAYING WITH A DOG
THE PRIEST FROM LEON DRINKING FROM A GOURD
TWO CHILDREN PLAYING WITH HANDMADE TOYS
ISELA COMING OUT OF ANOTHER TENT

text: PRICE RISES AND LOOKS AROUND THE CAMP, wandering over to large can where he drinks some water. CLAIRE EMERGES FROM THE TENT and watches Price head over a shaded area with his cameras.

head_text.subj: PRICE AS HE MOVES THROUGH A GROUP OF
SANDINISTAS GATHERED AROUND A TABLE

text: Their backs are toward us as he adjusts seating positions and rearranges items that have been provided for the tabl He takes a light reading and moves quickly into position. Price raises his camera.

head_text.subj: A TABLEAU OF RAFAEL, CINCO, AND SOLDIER

text: They sit at a table studying a map, a copy of La Prensa i displayed -- the headlines declare that RAFAEL IS DEAD an featuring a photo of Somoza at the luncheon as he points a map of the country. For an instant Rafael looks alive - FREEZE FRAME.

Price and Claire are sitting on top of a Red Cross truck it heads through Sebaco. Soldiers from La Guardia are  everywhere. As the truck moves through the village, somet catches Price's eyes: OATES STANDS AGAINST A WALL IN COMMAND OF A SQUADRON Two  whores and several troops sit against a wall. As the truc passes, Oates waves casually, with emotion.

Red light in the bathroom as Price pulls several photo pr from the bath and plasters them wet against the mirror. PHOTO OF RAFAEL IN THE CAMP, and he looks very much alive He pulls more shots from the bath: THE PRIEST FROM LEON, BUSINESSMAN, COMMANDANTE CINCO AND ISELA. He dries them o and hides them with their negatives under a pile of equip He picks up the shot of Rafael and leaves.
A group of muchachos in masks, baseball caps, and bandana race through the streets carrying a photo blow-up of Rafa
The newspaper headline sits on Jazy's desk as Jazy studie it unemotionally. We hear Miss Panama's voice:
Marcel!
He spins on his chair as she glides in modeling a new dre She spins magically for him -- he blows her a kiss.
A small private plane flies through a canyon, dwarfed by spectacular landscape. Hub Kittle works the room.
Two MASKED GUERILLAS hold a gun to the head of a pilot. A large sack is crammed into the tiny compartment with them

location: A SMALL MOUNTAIN TOWN IN NICARAGUA

text: The plane flies in low over the town and suddenly: THE SKY IS FILLED WITH LEAFLETS that flutter to the groun Townspeople, bewildered at first, pick up the papers to s
LOCAL RESIDENTS RAISE THEIR FISTS IN SALUTE to the plane it disappears into the mountains.

location: THE ROOFTOP GARDEN OF THE INTERCONTINENTAL

text: Journalists are gathered to watch the fighting which is n on the outskirts of Managua. Price stands to the side cas taking pictures of Journalists taking pictures of the war Hub Kittle floats around providing drinks and P.R. P.O.V. A PUSH-PULL AIRPLANE MAKES BOMBING PASSES on the  capitol. Columns of smoke rise throughout the city.

head_text.subj: REGIS MOVES HIS MINI-CAM CREW INTO POSITION AT THE RAIL

text: We got the smoke in frame?
(moves the camera  slightly) We got the smoke.
Roll it...
CLAIRE STANDS TO THE OTHER SIDE with binoculars watching. She accepts a drink from Hub and speaks into her tape dec

Under a steel gray July sky... start  again... under a gray steel Managuan  sky... scratch it... In an  extraordinary development in Managua,  President Anastazio Somoza has ordered  the Air Force to begin bombing his  own capitol, under a sky... fuck  it...
She fires down the drink and puts down the mike. She pick up the binoculars again and, glancing below, is shocked:
He starts into the hotel, glances up, and they see each o
Oh my God...

Price sees Alex at the same time. Alex waves to both of a he heads into the hotel. Price and Claire look at each ot Claire sits down at a table, stunned to see Alex. Price  commandeers a waiter and joins her with a fresh tray of  drinks.
A Scotch, please... (he nods) Double.
Price joins her as other journalists jockey for position the railing. He is equally upset and confused.
What's he doing here?
I have no idea.
ALEX COMES THROUGH THE DOOR with a couple journalists, se Price and Claire and comes over to join them. A polite ki on Claire's cheek, a handshake for Price. A moment of  awkwardness.
Congratulations.
On what?
On what?! The Washington Post, the  Times, networks, wire services --  everybody's picked up the picture.  It's fabulous.
(nervously) Well, yes... it's fabulous.
Fabulous.
Unsure silence.
Why are you back?
I came back because of Russell.
Because of me?

Yeah... the whole fucking East Coast  is falling in love with Rafael --  they were sure he was dead this time.  Somebody wants to do a musical about  him and his mug's on every T-shirt  in Central Park.
Alex enjoys the lunatic mixture of politics and popular  culture.
I think he's bigger than Farrah  Fawcett.
Claire and Price struggle to enjoy this supremely  uncomfortable moment. It's not easy to enter the game. Cl attempts to change the subject.
You look good. Things're okay?
I'm happier in New York, sure, things  are great. You guys?
Terrific... now... I'm a little slow  here, Alex... what exactly did you  come back for?
No more games. Alex addresses Price with conviction.
It's a great story. (beat) I want to talk to Rafael... and you're  the only man in the world that can  take me to him.

Price's and Claire's hearts sink. They look at each other Alex, despite his reluctance to return to Nicaragua, seem genuinely enthused about the possible story. Before Price Claire respond, Hub Kittle notices Alex and comes over wi a tray of drinks, extending genuine greetings to the Seni Correspondent.
Alex! Couldn't stay away, eh?
The fresh round of drinks are put on the table. The sound bombs ripping the capitol are the only thing we hear.
Claire and Price now have adjoining rooms. She is staring out the window as he comes in. The mood is strained.
We've got to tell Alex what happened.
No way.
I'll tell him. He deserves to know.
We don't owe him anything!

We owe him that! (beat) He got you started in this business...  he covered for your missed deadlines  and made excuses for your  unprofessional attitude before the  world fell in love with your  pictures... (beat) Before kids fresh out of journalism  school were rushing off to any war  they could to interview bullets and  take pictures of bodies -- like Price! (beat) He took care of you before you were  hot!
Silence. She's hitting home but he doesn't want to acknow it.
He wouldn't understand.
Before Nicaragua you wouldn't  understand. I'm not sure I exactly  understand. (beat) What are we going to do?
There is something calculating in Price's tone, this is n the fearless, boyish innocent anymore.

I'll take Alex to find Rafael --  we'll go to Sebaco on the road to  Matagalpa -- the Guardia heavily  control the area and they're scared  right now -- they'll never let us  through. We won't be able to get  near Rafael. Alex will understand --  and we'll turn around and drive back  without a story.
Claire is disturbed at this compounding of the lie.
That's a lie!
Tell me about lies!
Silence. They are co-conspirators and they know it.
I don't want to tell him either.

Price's white flagged newly rented press car streaks alon overtaking an ox cart. A guardia convoy is going the oppo direction, back toward Managua. Alex looks out of the car with interest--he hasn't been to the front line for sever wars.
We may not be able to find him,  y'know...
I've got supreme confidence in you.
A car is on fire by the side of the road. Price flies pas Alex watches curiously. Several people stand around the c
Claire looks good, eh?
Everybody looks good in the tropics.
Alex isn't sure how to respond to this curious reply.
Since I haven't been able to find  Isela since coming back, you're going  to have to translate for me -- what  the hell does that mean?
Price is nervous, wired, on edge.
Alex... I love her.
Alex takes this calmly -- it's not exactly new informatio
And she 'thinks' she loves you.
It's past the thinking stage.
Alex looks at the passing scenery -- he's in no hurry.
I'd like to know something -- it  probably doesn't matter in the great  final scheme of things... but I'm  interested... (beat) Did you ever lay a hand on her before  she left me?
No!
That's the truth?
Yes! (beat) Alex -- we're friends!
There is something desperate in his voice.

location: A ROADBLOCK ON THE EDGE OF SEBACO

text: Price and Alex are ordered out of their car by a very  unfriendly Guardia soldier. He is ordered to put down his camera bag. The hood and trunk are opened.
Venga.

They are led to a shed by the roadside, A TIRE REPAIR SHO where they sit down in an oily, dusty shack. They watch t soldiers: P.O.V. THE SOLDIERS TEARING UP THE RENTAL CAR, pulling of door panels, looking for weapons.
I bet you go through a few rental  cars.
Don't worry. I put this in your name.

PRICE AND ALEX JERK TO LIFE at the sound of screaming in distance. A volley of gunfire follows. Price moves quickl into an adjoining shed and looks through a crack in the w P.O.V. AN EXECUTION SQUAD IN A FIELD as several bodies ar being hauled away. Two soldiers reload their guns. PAN to figure moving behind a wall -- OATES.

head_text.subj: PRICE HURRIES THROUGH THE SHACKS TOWARD THE EXECUTION WAL

text: as Alex calls to him and hurries after -- Price is single minded. As he moves through the shacks we hear another vo of fire, and Price bursts into a clearing to see:

head_text.subj: TWO TRUCKS BEING LOADED WITH BODIES AS OATES SUPERVISES.
PRICE STEPS INTO THE CLEARING

text: They look at each other for several beats before anyone  speaks. Oates is slightly embarrassed.
No pictures, eh? Might look bad.
Oates smiles half-way; Price looks around at the bodies.
You get paid by the body or by the  hour?
I get paid the same way you do. What  the fuck you doin' in Sebaco -- this  place's about to blow... ain't it?
You didn't have to nail Pedro.
Who's Pedro?
Alex arrives and tries to pull Price back -- at the same  time he sees the bodies and is sickened at the sight.
Oh my God...
A body is carried through and loaded on a truck. Oates's  tone is one of explanation rather than defense, very matt of-fact.
There's a motherfucking war goin'  on, pal... lotta sad stories.
Price mumbles and wanders to the next truck a few feet aw and as he sees it he stops short, speechless. He points:

head_text.subj: THE BODIES OF THE PRIEST FROM LEON AND THE BUSINESSMAN,

text: figures we saw at Rafael's camp, sit in the back of the t They are splattered with blood and lifeless. Price is sha
Why them? Why them?!
Oates has to look to see who he's talking about, and Pric loses his cool.
You're a cocksucker!
I don't suck no dick, man...

PRICE GRABS OATES AND PUSHES HIM BACKWARDS but Oates resp like an animal. The two men go down in a heap and lash ou at each other in the dust. Their fighting is largely  ineffective, though very physical, until Oates asserts hi and knocks Price against a wall, breaking free to pick up his automatic rifle that he handles with one hand and sho it into Price's face.

I'd prefer not splattering your brains  in a dump like this -- I got  priorities. (to Alex) Guy wants to be a hero, pops, get  him outta here before he's a number. (beat) Be a shitty little town to buy it  in. (beat) Who are you?
Russell, let's get outta here.
(to Oates) Fuck you.
Guy's got a sense of humor, old man. (beat) Got any dope? Tough place to find  decent dope?
Why them?
Them? C'mere. You too.

He leads them under an awning nearby where a couple soldi sit. A small table, some weapons, two shallow boxes, food beer. Oates rummages around to find what he wants, and pu out: A HANDFUL OF PHOTOGRAPHS, mostly snapshots, odd sizes, wi names written on them. He sifts through them quickly and see an assortment of photographs of Nicaraguans. He finds what he's looking for and holds up: PRICE'S PHOTOGRAPH OF THE PRIEST AND THE BUSINESSMAN, the picture taken in Rafael's camp, blown up, cropped, and  identified. The faces are circled.
If your mug shows up in this box...  and ya try to make it through  Sebaco... I owe yer ass.
This information hits Price in the gut, and he is seized  with fear.
Who gives you the pictures?
What's this, an interview? I ain't  that dumb.
Price turns, he doesn't want to face it.
Off the record.
Off the record... some pachuco gives  'em to me. Ain't none of my business,  but I heard he gets 'em from a Frog.
Oates pulls another picture from a different box and hold it up:

head_text.subj: PHOTOGRAPH OF ISELA

text: Nice, eh?
She dead?
Not yet.
Alex grabs Price and heads back toward the roadblock.
Whatya' expect? We're the ones gettin'  our butts kicked.
Price hangs a U-turn at the roadblock and heads back to  Managua. He drives crazily.
Some-motherfucker-took-my-fucking- pictures-I-don't-fucking-know-what- happened! (beat) Fuck me!
Silence.
Didn't you ship the film to New York?
I developed it in my room. (pleads) Jesus Christ, Alex?!
Silence. The car races.
Slow down. (compassionately) It wasn't your fault if somebody  stole your stuff...
It was.
Alex doesn't force the issue, nor does he understand it  entirely.
What about Rafael?
No answer -- the car races back to Managua. Alex stares a Price trying to figure out what is wrong.

location: PRICE'S ROOM AT THE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL

text: A MAID IS CLEANING HIS ROOM which is the usual disaster.  Price enters, just returned, and quickly looks for his  negatives under the equipment where he had hidden them.
Algo no esta aqui. Fotografias. (Something is not  here. Photographs.)
(in Spanish) Everything's always a mess here. You  should be neater.
Negativos, negativos!
The maid shrugs -- Price is crazy anyway, and: CLAIRE WALKS INTO THE ROOM She too looks shaken. He looks up.
Commandante Cinco's body was just  found on the road to Matagalpa.
The maid starts crying. They look at her helplessly as sh sobs, 'Cinco, Cinco...'

A cab takes them through the increasingly nervous city. L Guardia troop trucks are everywhere -- things seem more  hurried. A hunting rifle sits in the cabbie's lap. They g out and knock on Jazy's door. GUARDIA SOLDIERS WATCH THEM FROM A DISTANCE, a developmen that Price and Claire are aware of.
I don't think it's Jazy.
Still no answer.
Oates said it was a Frog. How many  Frenchmen you know around here? Jazy  ain't 'facilitating' shit.

Price is impatient. He looks around nervously -- the Guar are out of view -- and he slides a knife into the latch,  jimmying the lock. The door opens slowly -- an alarm goes off. Price and Claire duck inside quickly.
Christ!

Price, momentarily comfortable with the danger, responds  quickly and finds the alarm wire running along the door j LA GUARDIA TROOPS NEARBY HEAR THE ALARM and head toward  Jazy's. INSIDE THE HOUSE PRICE FINDS THE ALARM BOX which he pries open and expertly pulls two wires. The alarm stops. Immediately they begin going through drawers and cupboard She pulls out some harmless snapshots of Miss Panama, rep them.
Are we looking for negs or prints?
Anything.
They find nothing downstairs. The look up at the sound of distant gunfire. Suddenly: Loud banging at the front door -- La Guardia.

location: TWO GUARDIA SOLDIERS AND A THIRD ARRIVING

text: They look around warily, hungrily -- they know something wrong. BACK INSIDE THE HOUSE we hear the shouting soldiers, bang Price and Claire look at each other, and the camera bag.  Claire points upstairs to Price, to the door for herself. Russell grabs the bag and bounds quickly upstairs. Claire goes to the front door, shaking nervously.

head_text.subj: CLAIRE OPENS THE DOOR AND FACES THE SOLDIERS

text: Que quiere? (What do you want?)
Donde esta senor Jazy?
No esta aqui.
Que quienes? (Who are you?)
(smiles) Una novia suya. (A girlfriend of his.)
The soldiers look at each other curiously and push open t door to look in the house without entering -- respectful Jazy.
El hombre tiene muchas novias, eh? (The man has many  girlfriends, no?)
The soldiers laugh and peer into the room. Claire forces door closed on them, teasing slightly.
No, no, no...
Afraid to make a mistake with one of Jazy's sweethearts,  they don't press the issue. The door closes shut.
CLAIRE sighs with frightened relief and hurries upstairs join Price. JAZY'S BEDROOM as she enters. A rumpled bed, a spilled wi glass -- a pleasant mess.
Russell? (no answer) Russell?

A door off the bedroom is open -- light spills out. Clair stops cold at what she sees: PRICE STANDS IN A ROOM FULL OF PHOTOGRAPHS Hundreds of  pictures of all sizes, photographic equipment, an enlarge cameras and lenses, etc. Pictures of Sandino, newspaper  photos, snapshots. P.O.V. OF RUSSELL'S PHOTOGRAPHS FROM RAFAEL'S CAMP croppe and blown up -- Commandante Cinco, the Priest of Leon, th Businessman, Isela. Photographs of other slain rebel lead The pictures include faces that have been circled with na written in -- exactly as in the pictures Oates possessed. They are both stunned.
Let's get out of here.

THEY HURRY DOWNSTAIRS and as they get to the front door - the sound of somebody opening it. They freeze. THE DOOR OPENS AND MISS PANAMA ENTERS She smiles and gree them in a friendly, aloof manner, and continues toward th waterless pool.
Hola.
Price and Claire return the greeting and continue out the door.

location: THE SOUND OF MORTAR IN THE DISTANCE

text: As they emerge, Claire tears a white cloth in half and ti it to a stick, handing half to Price who does likewise. An earth mover goes past, a Guardia soldier at the wheel. More soldiers cling to the machine, their guns at the rea
We've got to talk to Alex.
They start walking.
You think our flags are big enough?
Flags held high, they move nervously down the street into the ominous silence of the city.

Alex, Price, and Claire get out of a cab and approach a l statue of Somoza on horseback, surreally lit by floodligh in the center of a traffic circle. Four Guardia Soldiers visible on the sidewalk in the b.g. drinking with two wom
This is what I want to show you.
We drove through three roadblocks a  half hour before curfew so you could  show me a statue of Tacho.

It's not Tacho. It's Mussolini. Tacho  went to Italy to commission a statue  of himself, he found a warehouse  full of Il Duces on horseback, got a  great deal on one of 'em -- brought  it back and switched heads. (beat) Ya can't tell, can ya?
Silence. Alex knows Price too well -- it's a great story that's not why they're here.
What the hell are you talking about?
I think what he's trying to say --  what we're trying to say -- is that  things aren't exactly what they seem  to be.
Well, they don't "seem" to be that  great so I can't wait for this one... (mocks silliness) Hey, here we are! Two guys in the  tropics in love with the same dame...  bullets flying!
Alex! That's not why we're here.

Oh yeah? I left the country because  of him... (points to Price) ...and I came back because of him... (beat) And now the cutest couple in town  has me looking up a horse's ass on a  midnight tour of Managua. (points up the statue's  ass) What are we doing here?
Silence. Claire addresses Alex calmly.
Rafael is dead.
Silence. Alex isn't quite sure he understood.
In the picture he's dead?
(shouts) Dead!
How the hell...
(interrupts quickly) Who cares how?!
Silence. A bit of gallows laughter from Alex as he circle the statue. Price calms and tries to explain.
Alex... I think I finally saw one  too many bodies. (beat) Somoza is a killer. (beat) I thought the war would end sooner. (beat) How many reasons do you want?
You saw too many bodies? That's a  lot of bodies. (beat; to Price) You stupid son of a bitch. (to Claire) Did he talk you into it?
No! I wanted Rafael to be alive.
In some way I understand him doing  it, I don't like it but I  understand... but you?
I'd do it again.
Alex lets it all sink in. These two people about whom he such passionate feelings have totally exposed themselves him.
You two have, of course, just served  me up your balls -- if that's what  they're called -- on a platter. (several beats) I can bury you both. You're handing  me your careers.
They don't respond -- he's right.
Well, Jesus Christ... this is a  motherfucking story, Russell... (long silence) What am I supposed to do with it?
Anything you want.
Small, tired gallows laughter from Alex. There is a long  silence before Alex speaks, aware of the irony.
They're holding the lead in the World  section for Rafael.
It's great stuff, isn't it? We'd go  down in a blaze of glory.
Oh yeah... (distraught) I don't know what to do. (beat) I've gotta take some kind of a story  back with me. Maybe Jazy, eh?
Oh Jesus.
It's a little dangerous looking for  Jazy at the moment.
(mock heroic) Ah, danger -- I love it. You could  ask the pointy-shoed little bastard  about your pictures... and I could  ask him whatever happened to Isela.
She's an officer in the Rafael army --  we saw her in Matagalpa.
Alex is surprised slightly, but takes pleasure in reveali it.
You mean I slept with a Sandinista?
Price and Claire exchange glances. Alex is dead serious.
I guess Rafael is alive, eh?
PRICE AND CLAIRE LIE IN BED sweating. A siren and distant mortar can be heard outside. Price goes to the window and shuts it -- the room is quieter and hotter. He pounds a b air conditioning duct.
Damn air conditioning.
He looks out the window -- it never used to be this  complicated.
I wish I was home.
Silence.
C'mere.
She goes to him, lies down, and they embrace.
Do you think it's almost over?
A loud, long burst of automatic weapons fire is heard  somewhere outside. Their eyes are open as they hold onto  each other.

A sense of foreboding. Heavy road equipment prowls the st looking for Rebel barricades to destroy. Tanquettas and  Guardia everywhere. The flag draped press car of Price and Alex drives slowly P.O.V. OUT OF THE CAR AS THEY LOOK CAREFULLY Things feel  wrong. Guardia barricades are everywhere, forcing them to follow a route they might not choose. The Guardia soldier at the barricades seem on edge. When Jazy's house is visi in the distance, barricades force them another direction. GUARDIA SOLDIERS RACE DOWN A STREET TOWARD GUNFIRE and th car stops. When the road is clear it creeps into an  intersection. They check their position. THE CAR CREEPS TO A STOP and they look around further.

head_text.subj: A PIG CROSSES THE STREET 100 YARDS AWAY AND IS SHOT BY A
SOLDIER.

text: Everything is wrong. Price looks around restlessly.
Alex... let's go back.
Jazy's probably sitting in the bar  laughing at us. Which way's the hotel?
I don't know.

head_text.subj: A WOMAN PEEKS OUT OF A DOORWAY WATCHING

text: I'll ask her... be right back.
Just a sec'... take a flag.

But Alex is out of the car at once, approaching the woman Alex motions that "it's not necessary" and talks to the w We can't hear, but she points down the block. INSIDE THE CAR Price cranks film into place, his actions automatic and nervous. When he looks up:

Walking in the direction she pointed, he motions to Price if to say, "Just checking this out." PRICE LOOKS AROUND NERVOUSLY FOR A SENSE OF DIRECTION And he does, looks through the camera. THROUGH CAMERA P.O.V. OF THE DEAD PIG followed by quick  blurred pans to other images -- TANK, HOUSE, WOMAN, SOLDI until it settles on ALEX IN THE INTERSECTION. Two Guardia soldiers come up to him and he holds out his hands as if say, "I'm lost." ALEX TALKS TO THE SOLDIERS -- FREEZE FRAME click, click - and the whirring sound of a motor drive, another FREEZE F click, click, more whirring -- Price is on automatic pilo Another soldier orders Alex up against a wall. Nobody sees Price taking pictures -- it happens too quick
BLANK RANGE -- FREEZE FRAMES click, click, whirring as th images blur and the camera is dropped.

head_text.subj: PRICE STARES WITHOUT THE CAMERA

text: P.O.V. ALEX LIES DEAD AS THE SOLDIERS LOOK AROUND The act was random, almost nonchalant. PRICE STARTS TO RUN TOWARD ALEX shouting madly.
You fucks! You fucks!
He stops quickly as they see him, realizing how exposed h is. THE GUARDIA START FIRING AT HIM, realizing the murder was recorded.
Fotografia!
PRICE LEAPS IN HIS CAR and starts it up, racing around th corner as bullets rip into the car. THE WINDOW SHATTERS, AND PRICE IS HIT IN THE SHOULDER He  clutches his bleeding arm as he races on.
THE CAR GRINDS TO A HALT and Price leaps from it, racing  into a maze of ramshackle huts.
A hastily called press conference. Tacho takes a quick dr on a cigarette and makes the announcement.
It is with grave concern that we  announce that Alexander Grazier,  senior American correspondent, has  been murdered at the hands of  terrorists...
A shock wave goes through the room -- hands raised, quest
Mr. Kittle has prepared statements  for you.
Somoza turns and leaves as Kittle passes out press statem
TV is on. She's at the typewriter working on a story. A PHOTOGRAPH OF ALEX COMES ON THE TELEVISION NEWS, with  Spanish language commentary over the image.

head_text.subj: CLAIRE KEEPS WORKING AND GRADUALLY TYPES LESS AS SHE HEAR

text: the story, finally rising and moving in front of the  television as a local newsman reads of Alex's death and w see the Somoza press announcement. The phone rings: Claire picks up the phone and listens  silently before hanging up. She sits down shakily on the and starts crying.

PRICE HURRIES THROUGH the passageways between tin shacks, through tiny yards of goats and chickens, through houses poor that the war has nearly passed them by. Price is hur and looks around with fear to see: THE GUARDIA SOLDIERS MOVE DOWN INTO THE SHANTYTOWN, fanni out to quickly engulf the barrio. They move quickly. A HELICOPTER GUNSHIP MOVES IN LOW over the barrio and ope up sporadic outbursts of fire to insure nobody will try t flee. PRICE RUNS DOWN AN ALLEY and nearly runs right into the  Guardia. He hides behind a paper thin wall of flattened b cans -- the Guardia move past him only inches away. Price starts off in another direction, but Guardia appear -- he trapped in the barrio.
Journalists are everywhere -- suitcases packed -- trying get out of the country. The registration desk is chaos. R tries to get the attention of the clerk -- so does everyo else.
Get my bill and get me a cab, hey,  amigo!
The clerk is under attack.
No cabs.
Cabs!
No cabs!

head_text.subj: CLAIRE GETS OFF THE ELEVATOR AND MOVES THROUGH THIS CHAOS

text: Regis sees her and tries to give her comfort -- she's bey that. She wears a jacket and carries her bag -- she's goi somewhere.
I'm sorry, Claire...
She pushes him away politely; she is single-minded now.
Heard from Russell?
Nobody has.
Wanta help me find him?
Regis looks at her like she's crazy.
Claire... it's on the weird side out  there...
Hub Kittle enters the lobby, sees Claire and volunteers:
Jesus Christ, Claire, a human tragedy,  what can I say?
Claire is nearly in tears, but resists.
Fuck off, Hub, get outta my way.

head_text.subj: CLAIRE EXITS THE HOTEL AND GETS INTO HER PRESS CAR
JAZY'S HOUSE

text: Claire stays in her car and watches the house -- no way t get close -- and she continues driving, her route dictate by the same barricades that directed Alex and Price. She passes the dead pig in the street, and TWO RED CROSS  WORKERS make their way slowly around a corner, frightened Claire gets out of her car and approaches them.
(in Spanish) Do you know where the American  journalist was killed?
They all point down a street. She shows them the polaroid Price and her.
(in Spanish) Have you seen him?
They haven't and continue on their way. Claire walks in t direction they pointed -- no street fighting but many Gua
PRICE HUNCHES DOWN AND CRAWLS BEHIND THE STALLS as soldie move through the yards looking for him.

head_text.subj: A WOMAN IN A DOORWAY WATCHES PRICE HIDE
THE WOMAN APPEARS IN A DOORWAY AND MOTIONS WITH HER HEAD

text: Price to dart inside.
Nothing is said. Price is led into a room, one of many -- but this room is boarded over. There is no escape. Price in pain, his arm bleeds, he's tiring.
(in Spanish) This is the best I can offer.
Gracias.

head_text.subj: PRICE STANDS IN THE TINY ROOM WAITING

text: He leans against the wall behind the door. He shuts his e a noise at the door. When he opens them:

head_text.subj: THE WOMAN IS STANDING THERE WITH A GUN

text: She hands it to him and leaves, bolting the door. PRICE LEANS AGAINST THE WALL HOLDING A REVOLVER and he wa cameras around his neck, gun in hand, bloody, slightly  ridiculous, and scared.

Price's shot up car is not far away, but she's afraid to  approach it. She shows the picture of Price to a small bo who doesn't recognize it. GUARDIA SOLDIER SPOTS CLAIRE and walks toward her. She ca tell if the act is routine or threatening. He calls out t her.
Venga aqui.
She hesitates -- Alex is dead, everything is crazy. She s toward him, then changes her mind, turns, and walks quick away from him.

head_text.subj: THE SOLDIER RUNS TOWARD HER

text: CLAIRE RUNS FASTER and darts into a narrow passageway beh a house, where she looks back. He calls for support -- se join him and hurry after her. Panicky, she runs between  houses. OVERHEAD PLANES BUZZ THE NEIGHBORHOOD as Claire emerges f the 'maze' to see: P.O.V. PRICE'S CAR ABANDONED and full of holes near the s town. Guardia are everywhere. The helicopter gunship is  overhead.
He hears the Guard breaking in, and he cocks his gun.
as the Squadron Leader and three soldiers burst in -- the woman stands in the middle of the room and lies.
(in Spanish) Nobody is here. Get out.
The Sqaudron Leader points to different rooms for each  soldier, and they proceed to kick in each door, automatic rifles ready. PRICE'S ROOM AS HE HEARS A SOLDIER AT THIS DOOR.

head_text.subj: THE DOOR IS KICKED OPEN, AND A SOLDIER STEPS INTO THE ROO

text: For a moment he doesn't see Price -- then he whirls and f the photographer who's so scared he's forgotten to raise gun. PRICE AND THE SOLDIER ARE FACE-TO-FACE The soldier is a  fourteen-year-old boy fighting back tears. He, too, is sc to death. Neither is quite sure why he is there -- they j want it to end. PRICE AND THE BOY AIM THEIR GUNS AT EACH OTHER as they he the voice of the Squadron Leader in the other room.
Esta alli?! (Is he there?)
No answer.
Esta alli?!
SQUADRON LEADER HEADS TOWARD THE ROOM but as he does, the boy soldier appears in the doorway.
No esta aqui.

The Leader grunts an order, and the squadron quickly head to the next house. PRICE'S BODY SLUMPS AGAINST THE WALL EXHAUSTED, and the w enters as soon as the last soldier has gone. Price's brief moment of peace is shattered by the screami of Guardia troops and the explosions of rocket fire from gunship. He looks outside. THE GUNSHIP FIRES INTO THE SHANTYTOWN killing several of own Guardia troops. A GUARDIA OFFICER screams at the guns and fires a hand gun at the giant chopper.
(in Spanish) We are you! We are you! What are you  doing?!

GUARDIA TROOPS EVACUATE THE SHANTYTOWN in a panicky scram to escape their own gunship. PRICE RACES THROUGH THE BACK OF THE SHANTYTOWN, taking  advantage of the chaos, and without slowing down, breaks  free of the maze of the barrio. CLAIRE'S P.O.V. OF PRICE RACING ACROSS THE STREET, past a body and an overturned, smoking car, back into the rubble strewn blocks of the edge of the city. A tanquetta comes  around a corner and sees Price a block away.
Russell!
PRICE SEES HER, and races along a wall until they meet,  grabbing her on the run -- each is panicky and frightened and they duck into very shallow cover, barely safe.
What're you doing here?!
They embrace quickly and tightly, but look around nervous as they do. Price isn't sure if anybody knows about Alex.
Alex!
The Guardia did it -- I got pictures.

P.O.V. A TANQUETTA PASSES ON THE NEXT STREET, visible thr shattered holes in the buildings. A Guardia squadron pass PRICE AND CLAIRE RUN DOWN THE STREET in the opposite  direction, their path guided somewhat by an overturned bu in an intersection, abandoned barricades and roadblocks, the rubble of street fighting.

PRICE AND CLAIRE hesitate at the corner and move slowly a seeing two Sandinistas, dressed half in camouflaged gear, half disco. The TWO GUERRILLAS seem to control the street Price and Claire approach warily.
Hola. (the Guerrillas nod;  in Spanish) Do you control this area?
The Sandinista looks at his comrade, then looks around  nervously, frightened, then shrugs.
(in Spanish) I don't know.

Price and Claire continue on down the street and  simultaneously noticed something strange: THE DOOR TO JAZY'S HOUSE IS WIDE OPEN They approach caref and look in a view to the court-yard. Claire sticks her h in the door slowly, and as she does: A GIANT HAND GUN IS STUCK IN HER TEMPLE as TWO MUCHACHOS  quickly seize her and Price, dragging them inside.

JAZY STANDS WITH A THIRD GUN AT HIS HEAD, being held by t most forceful and crazed of three young Muchachos. With g on Jazy, Price, and Claire, there is much confusion as to who's in charge and what exactly they're doing.
(in Spanish) Who are you?
They are my friends.
(in Spanish) Shut up. We kill them all.
(in Spanish) No. Only him.
The guns are aimed back and forth in confusion -- Price a Claire don't have a chance to respond, and they're not su what to say.
(in Spanish) Him or him or her?
The Muchachos begin arguing rapidly among themselves; and they do, Jazy addresses Price and Claire coolly.
Well, here we are, eh?
(in Spanish) Assassin! Shut up!
The boys are confused -- they think  I had their family killed.
You murder people.
"Murder" is a word for criminals. I  have a job to protect the stability  of a continent.
Pig! Hijo de puta!
Please...
He is not begging for his life as much as for them to cal down.
You got caught by some boys?
Yes. Poets too, I imagine. (beat) Is your recorder on?
(hesitates) Yes.
Good. I have a speech to make.
The Muchachos don't understand what he's saying, but they stop to listen to his style. The guns remained trained on all three.

I like you people, but you are  sentimental shits. You fall in love  with the poets, the poets fall in  love with the Marxists, the Marxists  fall in love with themselves. The  country is destroyed with rhetoric,  and in the end we are stuck with  tyrants.
(in Spanish) Shut up!
Jazy turns to the boy who jams the gun into his head and  speaks with tired authority.
Un minuto, por favor.
(to Price and Claire,  more calmly) Who are you?
(in Spanish) They are journalists.
The Muchachos are immediately surprised and delighted, an one of them speaks in excited, broken English.
Periodistas! Take this picture! I'm  going to blow his head off.
The Muchachos quickly withdraw their guns from Price and  Claire and aim them all at Jazy's head.

Somoza? He is a tyrant too, of course.  A butcher. (beat) But finally that is not the point,  you see. If we wish to survive -- we  have a choice of tyrants, and for  all the right reasons, your poets  choose the wrong side.
(impatiently) Fotografia!
No.

Yes. (beat) Your picture of Rafael was  brilliant... but I am alive, and  better looking. A good looking  Frenchman with a sympathetic face is  murdered in cold blood while fighting  for the survival of Europe and  America. (beat) You will have another magazine cover! (smiles) Muy complicado, no?
(in Spanish) Ready! Now!
You picked the wrong side.
In fifty years we will know who's  right. (beat) Are you going to take the picture as  the bullet enters the skull or as it  comes out? This wall's a nice color,  eh? I can move into the sunlight.
CLAIRE TURNS AND WALKS AWAY, her back to the scene.
(to Claire) It's just a story!
PRICE REMAINS AND STARES AT JAZY as the Muchachos grow  increasingly impatient. Some part of him wants to take th picture.
(in Spanish) Shut up!
They say that if somebody's holding  a gun on you, you should never stop  talking... that's the theory -- who  knows?...
PRICE TURNS AND WALKS AWAY toward Claire. Still -- Jazy t
Maybe it's a good thing that I talk  too much...

head_text.subj: A GUNSHOT RINGS OUT.

text: Price grimaces. Claire shuts her eyes. They turn to look the fallen Jazy as the Three Muchachos, frightened by the own act, race back into the street. For several moments P and Claire stand, frozen, until the rumbling sound of a  helicopter gunship nearby forces them to hurry outside. PRICE AND CLAIRE GO TO THE DOORWAY and look out as a jeep full of Guardia screams past
TANQUETTA a block away. The neighborhood seems to be chan hands again. Price and Claire slump in the darkness near the doorway; touches near his wounded arm.
You okay? (he nods) Russell... what did Alex do?
Nothing. He asked for directions.
She shakes her head and leans it against Price's shoulder but the distant popping of guns does not even allow her a moment of mourning. Their heads pop up nervously.
We gotta get outta sight -- half the  fucking army's looking for me...
They're not looking for me.
Silence.
Let me have the film... (beat; unsure) ...if I can't get to the hotel I'll  come back here...
Price doesn't want her to go alone, but he's not that exc about hiding out in the middle of the city either.
Aw, Christ... (frustrated) I've wrecked everything else, at  least let me take care of you here.
Russell... it's more dangerous being  with you than being alone.

He knows she's right. He loves her, and he's made enough  disastrous decisions lately. He hesitates, then pops open his camera and removes the film. Price ties the film into the white flag that hangs from a stick stuck into her bel

head_text.subj: PRICE AND CLAIRE EMBRACE AND KISS BRIEFLY

text: Don't get hurt.
(affectionately) That's great advice.

They kiss, and Claire runs out after a Red Cross truck. P watches nervously until they turn a corner, out of sight, then goes back inside Jazy's courtyard. PRICE NEARLY STUM OVER JAZY'S BODY, stops, stares -- he'd forgotten already The body makes him uneasy, and after several moments he f a sheet and covers Jazy. Price then sits down and waits  nervously, sharing the courtyard with Jazy.
CLAIRE WALKS ALONGSIDE THE RED CROSS TRUCK as it comes ar a corner. The truck turns one direction, she wants to go other way toward the hotel.

head_text.subj: THE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL ON THE HILL IN DISTA
DUSK

text: Guardia troops heavily patrol the ground between Claire a the hotel -- a jeep, a troop carrier, a tanquetta, and fi foot soldiers. CLAIRE TAKES TEMPORARY COVER offered by a MIDDLE-AGED WOM who sees that she is afraid of La Guardia. Claire steps b a walled yard. Moments later: A BOY ON A BIKE RIDES SLOWLY OUT OF THE YARD and turns up the hill toward the Guardia and the hotel. Claire's white flag is tied to his handlebars. CLAIRE WATCHES FEARFULLY as the boy pedals into the milit zone. The woman offers Claire some food; she declines.

location: THE ROAD TO THE INTERCONTINENTAL HOTEL

text: THE BOY PEDALS slowly, in no hurry, past La Guardia troop Some of them watch him curiously, some ignore him. The wh flag flutters as he rides.

CLAIRE RETRACES HER STEPS to the block where Price is hid in Jazy's house. THE TWO DISCO SANDINISTAS LIE DEAD IN THE STREET, a dog s at the bodies. Claire looks around -- there is little sig of life. She enters Jazy's house.
CLAIRE ENTERS and stops. She calls out his name, no answe Price is gone. She hurries back outside.

TWO GUARDIA TROOP CARRIERS RACE PAST, sirens screaming, l with Guardia soldiers. Claire steps into the street unsur looking every direction. PEOPLE BEGIN COMING OUT OF THEIR HOMES and what remains o their small homes. They come one at a time at first, then small groups, carrying belongings, pets, chickens, etc. CLAIRE SHOWS A PICTURE OF PRICE AND HER to a woman who co out of the house next to Jazy's, but the woman shakes her head, not recognizing Price. A PUSH-PULL PLANE DIVES IN LOW FIRING ROCKETS at the home THE CROWD GROWS and chaotically flees the destruction,  gradually finding a direction out of the city. Claire is  swept along in the crowds, at first without choice, then  finally fleeing for her life with the rest of Managua. As she moves with the crowd, she looks for Price everywhere, without success.

SEVERAL CAMPFIRES burn near the edge of the city where do have taken temporary refuge. Claire arrives to see: A BOD ON A STRETCHER BEING CARRIED up outside stairs to a rooft from which glow several bare bulbs. She goes up the stair to the rooftop.

A MAKESHIFT MOBILE HOSPITAL under awnings and palm fronds capable of moving location in minutes. A WOMAN DOCTOR and two temporary orderlies tend to wounded. A small black an white television sits on a table and those who are able w the seige of Managua on television while it goes on aroun them. Claire looks for Price among the dead or wounded.

head_text.subj: THE CITY UNDER ATTACK

text: Claire watches for several moments -- smoke, flame, the  buzzing sound of planes swooping low, fleeing crowds. She then notices the television. PRICE'S FOOTAGE OF ALEX'S DEATH comes on the TV screen, a she pushes closer to see the grim sequence. The NEWS  COMMENTATOR explains in Spanish what we see CLAIRE IS SO  DISTURBED AT THE IMAGES that she turns away, sickened, hu guilty, outraged, but unable to break down. She closes he eyes -- her face is covered with tears. The Doctor notice this and speaks softly to her.

Journalist? (Claire nods) You knew the man who was killed? (she nods again) Fifty thousand Nicaraguans have  died... and now one Yankee. (beat) Perhaps now Americans will be outraged  at what is happening here, eh?
It takes a while for Claire to respond.
Yes... perhaps they will.
Noise in the distance from mortars. The Doctor speaks cal without bitterness in the voice, but with total convictio
Maybe we should have killed an  American journalist fifty years ago.

Claire acknowledges the grim truth of the observation wit slight nod, and walks to the railing as: ALEX'S DEATH IS REPEATED IN FREEZE FRAME SEQUENCE over an over again as the Orderlies, Doctor, and patients gather watch with fascination. CLAIRE STARES OUT AT THE CITY ON FIRE, when her eye catch something -- a light in the sky. She watches:

head_text.subj: A HELICOPTER WITH SEARCHLIGHT PASSES OVERHEAD,

text: momentarily illuminating the hospital, but it continues o curiously uninterested in the Guerrilla activity. The cho sweeps above a nearby hill and hovers, then slowly lowers earth. CLAIRE WATCHES with interest then descends the stairs.

SOMOZA WATCHES AS A BACK HOE DIGS UP THE COFFINS of his  parents. An Army helicopter lands, lighting the scene, an Miss Panama rushes from the chopper into his arms as the  turbulence from the blades raises her dress and musses hi hair. Soldiers place the dirt-covered caskets on the roof of Somoza's two Mercedes, hastily tie them down, and the  strange motorcade, flanked by two heavily armed jeeps, dr off into the dark. CLAIRE WATCHES IT ALL from a safe distance, not far from refugee camp. She turns and walks slowly back to the camp

Claire sits down against the remains of a wall. The war h overtaken her -- she doesn't know if Price is alive -- an though totally involved, she is at last an observer once  again. Claire notices the tiny red light of her recorder still on. She turns it off, and as the sounds of battle  gradually die down, Claire falls asleep -- exhausted.

CLAIRE SLEEPS AGAINST THE WALL as a dog sniffs and licks face. She awakens with a start -- the dog scurries away.  Claire rises and looks around. A LOCAL WOMAN PUSHES A CART carrying the wrapped body of husband through the otherwise quiet streets of Managua. CLAIRE MOVES THROUGH THE CAMP just coming to life, and lo around trying to interpret the eerie silence. A WOMAN ten to her TWO SMALL CHILDREN.
(in Spanish) Have you seen La Guardia?
(in Spanish) No. Is the war over?
(in Spanish) I don't know.
A DISTANT, DRONING NOISE GETS STEADILY LOUDER. Claire loo around nervously.

head_text.subj: A CHILD RUNS DOWN THE STREET SHOUTING

text: Tanquettas! Tanquettas!

P.O.V. -- SEVERAL TANQUETTAS AND EARTH MOVERS coming over the hill in the distance. The Refugees look up fearfully some hide. As the war machinery gets closer, we see that: SANDINISTAS ARE DRIVING THE MACHINES draped with red and  black (F.S.L.N.), blue and white (Nicaraguan), and yellow and white (the Vatican) flags. Graffiti of victory covers the tanquettas. PEOPLE COME INTO THE STREET CHEERING, embracing, only  gradually realizing what has happened.
(in Spanish) Is the war over?
Yes.
Es bueno. (It is good.)

The woman continues with her children, her comment  unemotional, and Claire smiles slightly and walks away,  through a city awakening slowly to its victory. CLAIRE STOPS A RED CROSS TRUCK and shows the driver her  picture of Price. The picture means nothing to the driver Claire continues through the city, looking for Price.
CLAIRE WALKS INTO THE POOL AREA where chairs and tables f in the pool, the bar is overturned, and the once sumptuou press oasis is a disaster.
CLAIRE ENTERS A DESERTED LOBBY, also a mess, and hesitate before climbing the circular stairs. CLAIRE LOOKS INTO PRICE'S ROOM, and finds it empty, and  typically messy.

head_text.subj: CLAIRE WALKS INTO HER OWN ROOM

text: looking out at the jubilant city from which smoke still r CLAIRE AND PRICE EMBRACE DEEPLY, holding onto each other  without the slightest intention of letting go.

PRICE AND CLAIRE COME DOWNSTAIRS to the lobby. They are  cleaned up in fresh clothes; they have survived and the w is over. THE LOBBY IS COMING TO LIFE AGAIN with Regis' camera crew who look like they've had a long night, a BUS BOY, A MAID AN OLD COUPLE, and A WHITE WOMAN, 38, with TWO SMALL DAUG all either sit or mill in the b.g. PRICE AND CLAIRE STOP SHORT at what they see.
Alex.

P.O.V. -- A HANDMADE CASKET SITTING IN THE LOBBY with the name, "A. Grazier" scrawled in felt pen. Price and Claire stand next to the box silently -- there nothing to say -- but the silence is interrupted by a fam voice that is polite, unforced, and sincere.
It was the best I would do under the  circumstances. The casket, I mean.
Awkward silence until they realize that he's sincere.
Can you help us ship it home?
I've already taken care of it. (beat) I always liked the guy. I can't even  get tickets for my own family, but I  could get you two on the plane if  you want.
We see the woman and little girls as Hub's family.
Yes, please...
Tacho's in Miami.
A shared silence at the lunacy of the moment, interrupted the tired voice of one of Hub's daughters.
Daddy!
(to Price and Claire) I am sorry. I had a job to do --  that's all -- it put me in some  unhappy situations.
Hub goes over to take care of his family.

Thousands of people have gathered to celebrate in loud an joyous singing, led by a group on the highest cathedral s surrounded by Revolutionary leaders waving to the crowds. SINGING GROUP sings a song to Nicaragua, and a song to Ra RAFAEL'S BODY IN A FANCY CASKET is carried in through the crowd to wild cheering and singing. High over the pallbea heads it moves through the crowds. PRICE AND CLAIRE STAND TO THE SIDE watching it all. The  celebration is joyously infectious, and for the moment we can forget the bloodshed, forget the problems that lay ah forget even the death of Alex. PRICE PULLS OUT A CAMERA and begins taking pictures of th celebration. ISELA IS AT THE MICROPHONE with other Guerrilla leaders. CLAIRE WORKS THROUGH THE CROWD with her mike held high,  recording the singing of the crowd. PRICE BACKS UNDER THE AWNING of a stand selling refreshme and especially Rum and Coke mixtures known suddenly and  triumphantly as "Nicalibres." As Price snaps off pictures a voice from an American in casual street clothes drinkin at the temporary bar.
Hey, Pricey...
Price looks over to see the smiling Oates.
It's all over, eh? We made it. I  like the singing.
What're you doing here?
Free country. Now it's free, anyway. (raises his drink) Nicalibre!
Oates holds up his Kodak Instamatic camera.
How 'bout a quickie? (no response) No? Things are heating up in  Thailand... thought I'd check it  out. (beat) You ain't gonna turn me in, are ya?

head_text.subj: PRICE TURNS AND WALKS AWAY

text: Am I gonna see ya in Thailand? We  could be friends!
Price keeps walking, into the crowd, where he finds Clair Oates orders another Nicalibre, and beats his foot to the music.

head_text.subj: PRICE AND CLAIRE IN THE CROWD

text: We've got a plane to catch.
Did you get enough pictures?
No answer -- a final complicated question from Claire --  they smile. Price waves for a cab which pulls over. They in the cab and drive away.

head_text.subj: HOLD ON THE VICTORY CELEBRATION
